editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

And lastly, the comicall passages of an Italian bridewell, where the scæne ends. Written by Thomas Dekker.

div.p: The second part of the honest whore, with the humours of the patient man, the impatient wife: the honest whore, persuaded by strong arguments to turn courtesan again: her brave refuting those arguments.
And lastly, the comical passages of an Italian Bridewell, where the scene ends.
London, printed by Elizabeth Allde, for Nathaniel butter. An. Dom. 1630.

sp.stage: Enter at one door Beraldo, Carolo, Fontinell, Astolfo, with serving-men, or pages attending on them; at another door enter Lodovico, meeting them.

sp.speaker: Lodovico.
sp.l: Good day, gallants.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good morrow, sweet Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: How dost thou Carolo.

sp.speaker: Carolo.
sp.p: Faith, as physicians do in a plague, see the world sick, and am well myself.

sp.speaker: Fontinell.
sp.l: Here's a sweet morning, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O, a morning to tempt Jove from his ningle Ganymede, which is but to give Dary wenches green gowns as they are going a milking; what, is thy lord stirring yet?

sp.speaker: Astolfo.
sp.l: Yes, he will not be horsed this hour, sure.

sp.speaker: Bercaldo.
sp.p: My lady swears he shall, for she longs to be at court.

sp.speaker: Carolo.
sp.p: O, we shall ride switch and spur, would we were there once.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How now, is thy lord ready?

sp.speaker: Bryan.
sp.p: No so crees sa me, my lady will have some little ting in her belly first.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: O, than they'll to breakfast.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Footman, does my lord ride ith' coach with my lady, or on horseback?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: No foot la, my lady will have me lord sheet wid her, my lord will sheet in de one side, and my lady sheet in de toder side.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My lady sheet in de toder side: did you ever here a rascal talk so like a pagan? Is't not strange that a fellow of his star, should be seen here so long in Italy, yet speak so from a christian?
sp.stage: Enter Anthonio, Georgio, a poor scholar.

sp.speaker: Aslol.
sp.p: An Irishman in Italy! that so strange! why, the nation have running heads.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay Carolo, this is more strange, I ha' been in France, there's few of them: marry, England they count a warm chimney corner, and there they swarm like crickets to the crevice of a brewhouse; but sir, in England I have noted one thing.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: What's that, what's that of England?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Marry this sir, what's he yonder?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: A poor fellow would speak with my lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: In England, sir, troth I ever laugh when I think on't: to see a whole nation should be marked i'th forehead, as a man may say, with one iron: why sir, there all costermongers are Irishmen.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: O, that's to show their antiquity, as coming from Eve, who was an apple-wife, and they take after the mother.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good, good, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why then, should all your chimney-sweepers likewise be Irishmen? answer that now, come, your wit.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Faith, that's soon answered, for s. Patrick you know keeps purgatory, he makes the fire, and his countrymen could do nothing, if they cannot sweep the chimneys.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Then, sir, have you many of them (Like this fellow) (Especially those of his hair) footmen to noblemen and others, and the knaves are very faithful where they love, by my faith very proper men many of them, and as active as the clouds, whirr, hah.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Are they so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And stout! exceeding stout; why, I warrant, this precious wild villain, if he were put to't, would fight more desperately than sixteen dunkerkes.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: The women they say are very fair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No, no, our country bona robaes ▪ o! are the sugar delicious rogues.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: O, look, he has a feeling of them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not I, I protest, there's a saying when they commend nations: it goes, the Irishman for his hand, Welshman for a leg, the Englishman for a face, the Dutchman for beard.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.l: I'faith, they may make swabbers of them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The Spaniard, let me see, for a little foot (I take it) the
Frenchman, what a pox hath he? and so of the rest.
Are they at breakfast yet? come walk.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This Lodovico, is a notable tongued fellow.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.l: Discourses well.

sp.speaker: Berc.
sp.l: And a very honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: Oh! he's well valued by my lord.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.l: How now, how now, what's she?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Let's make towards her.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Will it be long, sir, ere my lord come forth?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Would you speak with my lord?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
How now, what's this, a nurse's bill? hath any here
got thee with child, and now will not keep it?

sp.speaker: Bolla.
sp.l: No sir, my business is unto my lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He's about his own wife now, he'll hardly dispatch two causes in a morning.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: No matter what he says, fair lady, he's a knight, there's no hold to be taken at his words.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: My lord will pass this way presently.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: A pretty plump rogue.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: A good lusty bouncing baggage.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A pox on her, I was sure her name was in my table-book once, I know not of what cut her die is now, but she has been more common than tobacco: this is she that had the name of the honest whore.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Is this she?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This is the blackamoor that by washing was turned white: this is the birding piece new scoured: this is she that (If any of her religion can be saved) was saved by my lord Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: She has been a goodly creature.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She has been! that's the epitaph of all whores, I'm well acquainted with the poor gentleman her husband, lord! what fortunes that man has overreached? She knows not me, yet I have been in her company, I scarce know her, for the beauty of her cheek hath (Like the moon) suffered strange eclipses since I beheld it: but women are like medlars (No sooner ripe but rotten.)
sp.l: A woman last was made, but is spent first,
Yet man is oft proved, in performance worst.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: My lord is come.
sp.stage: Enter Hypolito, Infaeliche, and two waiting women.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We ha' wasted half this morning: morrow Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Morrow madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Let's away to horse.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ay, I to horse, to horse.

sp.speaker: Bela.
sp.p: I do beseech your lordship, let your eye read ere this wretched paper.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'm in haste, pray the good woman take some apter time.

sp.speaker: Insae.
sp.l: Good woman do.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O 'las! it does concern a poor man's life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Life! sweet heart? Seat yourself, I'll but read this and come.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What stockings have you put on this morning, madam? if they be not yellow, change them; that paper is a letter from some wench to your husband.

sp.speaker: Infae
sp.l: O sir, that cannot make me jealous.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your business, sir, to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes my good lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Presently sir; are you Matheo's wife.

sp.speaker: Bela.
sp.l: That most unfortunate woman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'm sorry these storms are fallen on him, I love Mathaeo.
And any good shall do him, he and I.
Have sealed two bonds of friendship, which are strong
In me, however fortune does him wrong;
He speaks here he's condemned. Is't so?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Too true.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What was he whom he killed? O, his name's here; old Lacomo, son to the Florentine Lacomo, a dog, that to meet profit, would to the very eyelids wade in blood of his own children. Tell Mathaeo, the Duke my father hardly shall deny his signed pardon, 'twas fair fight, yes if rumour's tongue go true, so writes he here.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning I return from court;
Pray be you here then. I'll have done sir straight:
But in troth say, are you Matheo's wife?
You have forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your turner,
That made you smooth to run an even bias,
You know I loved you when your very soul
Was full of discord: art not a good wench still?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Umph, when I had lost my way to heaven, you showest it:
I was new born that day.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
'Sfoot, my lord, your lady asks if you have not left
your wench yet? When you get in once, you never have done: come, come, come, pay your old score, and send her packing, come.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ride softly on before, I'll o'ertake you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your lady swears she'll have no riding on before, without ye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Prithee good Lodonico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My lord pray hasten.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I come: tomorrow let me see you, fare you well: commend me to Mathaeo: pray one word more: does not your father live about the court?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I think he does, but such rude spots of shame
Stick on my cheek, that he scarce knows my name.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Orlando Friscabaldo, is't not?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What does he for you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: All he should: when children
From duty start, parents from love may swerve.
He nothing does: for nothing I deserve.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Shall I join him unto you, and restore you to wonted grace?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is impossible.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It shall be put to trial: fare you well:
The face I would not look on I sure then 'twas rare,
When in despite of grief, 'tis still thus fair.
Now, sir, your business with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am bold to express my love and duty to your lordship in these few leaves.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A book!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes my good lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Are you a scholar?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, my lord, a poor one.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sir, you honour me.
King's may be scholars patrons, but faith tell me,
To how many hands besides hath this bird flown,
How many partners share with me?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Not one in troth, not one: your name I held more dear,
I'm not (My lord) of that low character.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your name I pray?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Antonio Georgio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Of Milan?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll borrow leave
To read you o'er, and then we'll talk: till then
Drink up this gold, good wits should love good wine,
This of your loves, the earnest that of mine.
How now, sir, where's your lady, not gone yet?

sp.speaker: Bryan.
sp.p: I fart di lady is run away from dee, a mighty deal of ground, she sent me back for dine own sweet face, I pray dee come my lord away, wilt tow go now?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Is the coach gone?
Saddle my horse the sorrel.

sp.speaker: Bryan.
sp.p: A pox a de horses nose, he is a lousy rascally fellow, when I came to gird his belly, his scurvy guts rumbled, di horse farted in my face, and dow knowest, an Irishman cannot abide a fart, but I have saddled de hobby-horse, di fine hobby is ready, I pray dee my good sweet lord, wit tow go now, and I will run to de devil before dee?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Well, sir, I pray let's see you master scholar.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.l: Come I pray dee, wilt come sweet face? Go.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: God's so, gentlemen, what do we forget?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Are not we all enjoined as this day, Thursday is't not? I as that day to be at the linendrapers house at dinner?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Signior Candido, the patient man.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: Afore Jove, true, upon this day he's married.

sp.speaker: Berc.
sp.p: I wonder, that being so stung with a wasp before, he dares venture again to come about the eaves amongst bees.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
O 'tis rare sucking a sweet honeycomb; pray heaven his old wife be buried deep enough, that she rise
not up to call for her dance, the poor fiddler's instruments would crack for it, she'd tickle them: at any hand let's try what mettle is in his new bride, if there be none, we'll put in some; troth it's a very noble citizen, I pity he should marry again, I'll walk along, for it is a good old fellow.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: I warrant, the wives of Milan would give any fellow twenty thousand ducats, that could but have the face to beg of the Duke, that all the citizens in Milan might be bound to the peace of patience, as the linen-draper is.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O fie upon't, 'twould undo all us that are courtiers, we should have no who with the wenches then.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: My lord's come.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How now, what news?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your lady is with the Duke her father.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And we'll to them both presently, who's that?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Signior Friscabaldo.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Friscabaldo, o! pray call him, and leave me, we two have business.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ho signior! Signior Friscabaldo.
The lord Hipollito.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: My noble lord: my lord Hipollito! the Duke's son! his brave daughters brave husband! how does your honoured lordship! does your nobility remember so poor a gentleman as signior Orlando Friscabaldo! old mad Orlando!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O sir, our friends! they ought to be unto us as our jewels, as dear valued, being locked up, and unseen, as when we wear them in our hands. I see, Friscabaldo, age hath not command of your blood, for all times sickle has gone over you, you are Orlando still.

sp.speaker: Orl,
sp.p:
Why my lord, are not the fields mown and cut
down, and stripped bare, and yet wear they not pied coats again? though my head be like a leek, white: may not my heart be like the blade, green?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Scarce can I read the storeys on your brow,
Which age hath writ there, you look youthful still.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: I eat snakes, my lord, I eat snakes.
My heart shall never have a wrinkle in it, so long as I can cry
Hem with a clear voice.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You are the happier man, sir.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: Happy man! I'll give you (My lord) the true picture of a happy man; I was turning leaves over this morning, and found it, an excellent Italian painter drew it, if I have it in the right colours, I'll bestow it on your lordship.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I stay for it.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: He that makes gold his wife, but not his whore,
He that at noonday walks by a prison door,
He that ith' sun is neither beam nor moat,
He that's not mad after a petticoat,
He for whom poor men's curses dig no grave,
He that is neither lords nor lawyer's slave,
He that makes this his sea, and that his shore,
He that in's coffin is richer than before,
He that counts youth his sword, and age his staff,
He whose right hand carves his own epitaph,
He that upon his death-bed is a swan,
And dead, no crow, he is a happy man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It's very well, I thank you for this picture.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: After this picture (My lord) do I strive to have my face drawn:
sp.l: For I am not covetous,
Am not in debt,
Sit neither at the Duke's side,
Nor lie at his feet.
Wenching and I have done, no man I wrong,
No man I fear, no man I fee;
I take heed how far I walk, because I know yonder's my home.
I would not die like a rich man, to carry nothing away save a winding sheet:
But like a good man, to leave Orlando behind me.
I sowed leaves in my youth, and I reap now books in my age.
I fill this hand, and empty this, and when the bell shall toll for me, if I prove a swan and go singing to my nest, why so?
If a crow! throw me out for carrion, and pick out mine eyes,
May not old Friscabaldo (My lord) be merry now! ha?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You may, would I were partner in your mirth.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: I have a little,
Have all things;
I have nothing; I have no wife, I have no child, have no chick, and why should not I be in my jocundare?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Is your wife then departed?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: She's an old dweller in those high countries,
Yet not from me,
sp.p: Here, she's here: but before me, when a knave and a quean are married, they commonly walk like sergeants together: but a good couple are seldom parted.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You had a daughter too sir, had you not?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: O my lord! this old tree had one branch, (And but one branch growing out of it) it was young, it was fair, it was straight; I pruned it daily, dressed it carefully, kept it from the wind, helped it to the sun, yet for all my skill in planting, it grew crooked, it bore crabs; I hewed it down,
sp.l: What's become of it, I neither know, nor care.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Then can I tell you what's become of it;
That branch is withered.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: So 'twas long ago.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Her name I think was Bellafront, she's dead.

sp.speaker: Orlando.
sp.l: Ha? dead?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yes, what of her was left, not worth the keeping,
Even in my sight was thrown into a grave.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Dead! my last and best peace go with her, I see deaths a good trencherman, he can eat course homely meat,
as well as the daintiest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why, Friscabaldo, was she homely?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: O my lord! A strumpet is one of the devil's vines; all the sins like so many poles are stuck upright out of hell, to be her props, that she may spread upon them. And when she's ripe, every slave has a pull at her, then must she be pressed. The young beautiful grape sets the teeth of lust on edge, yet to taste that liquorish wine, is to drink a man's own damnation. Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: She's turned to earth.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: Would she were turned to heaven; umh, is she dead! I am glad the world has lost one of his idols; no whoremonger will at midnight beat at the doors; in her grave sleep all my shame, and her own; and all my sorrows, and all her sins.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'm glad you are wax, not marble; you are made
Of man's best temper, there are now good hopes
That all these heaps of
Ice about your heart,
By which a father's love was frozen up,
Are thawed in these sweet showers fetched from your eyes,
We are ne'er like angels till our passion dies,
She is not dead, but lives under worse fate,
I think she's poor, and more to clip her wings,
Her husband at this hour lies in the jail,
For killing of a man, to save his blood,
Join all your force with mine: mine shall be shown,
The getting of his life preserves your own.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: In my daughter you will say! does she live then?
sp.p: I am sorry I wasted tears upon a harlot, but the best is I have a handkercher to drink them up, soap can wash them all out again.
sp.l: Is she poor?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Trust me, I think she is.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
Then she's a right strumpet; I ne'er knew any of their trade rich two years together; sieves can hold no
water, nor harlots hoard up money; they have many vents, too many sluices to let it out; taverns, tailors, bawds, panders, fiddlers, swaggerers, fools and knaves, do all wait upon a common harlot's trencher: she is the galley-pot to which these drones fly: not for love to the pot, but for the sweet sucket within it, her money, her money.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I almost dare pawn my word, her bosom gives warmth to no such snakes; when did you see her?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: Not seventeen summers.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Is your hate so old?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: Older; it has a white head, and shall never die till she be buried,
sp.l: Her wrongs shall be my bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Work yet his life, since in it lives her fame.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: No, let him hang, and half her infamy departs out of the world: I hate him for her; he taught her first to taste poison; I hate her for herself, because she refused my physic.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nay but Friscabaldo.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I detest her, I defy both, she's not mine, she's.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Hear her but speak.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I love no mermaids, I'll not be caught with a quail pipe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You're now beyond all reason.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I am then a beast. Sir, I had rather be a beast, and not dishonour my creation, then be a doting father, and like time, be the destruction of mine own brood.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Is't dotage to relieve your child being poor?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is't fit for an old man to keep a whore?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Tis charity too.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: 'Tis foolery; relieve her!
Were her cold limbs stretched out upon a beer,
I would not sell this dirt under my nails
To buy her an hour's breath, nor give this hair,
Unless it were to choke her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fare you well, for I'll trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
And fare you well sir, go thy ways, we have few
lords of thy making, that love wenches for their honesty; 'las my girl! art thou poor? poverty dwells next door to despair, there's but a wall between them; despair is one of hell's catchpoles; and lest that devil arrest her, I'll to her, yet she shall not know me; she shall drink of my wealth, as beggars do of running water, freely, yet never know from what fountains head it flows. Shall a silly bird pick her own breast to nourish her young ones, and can a father see his child starve? That were hard; the pelican does it, and shall not I. Yes, I will victual the camp for her, but it shall be by some stratagem; that knave there her husband will be hanged I fear, I'll keep his neck out of the noose if I can, he shall not know how.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: How now knaves, whither wander you?
To seek your worship.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Stay, which of you has my purse, what money have you about you?

sp.l: Some fifteen or sixteen pounds, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Give it me, I think I have some gold about me; yes, it's well; leave my lodging at court, and get you home. Come sir, though I never turned any man out of doors, yet I'll be so bold as to pull your coat over your ears.

sp.l: What do you mean to do sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Hold thy tongue knave, take thou my cloak, I hope I play not the paltry merchant in this bartering; bid the steward of my house, sleep with open eyes in my absence, and to look to all things, whatsoever I command by letters to be done by you, see it done. So, does it sit well?

sp.l: As if it were made for your worship.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You proud varlets, you need not be ashamed to wear blue, when your master is one of your fellows; away, do not see me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: This is excellent.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I should put on a worse suit too; perhaps I will.
sp.p: My vizard is on, now to this mask. Say I should shave off this honour of an old man, or tie it up shorter; well, I will spoil a good face for once. My beard being off, how should I look? even like
sp.l: A winter cuckoo, or unfeather owl;
Yet better lose this hair, then lose her soul.
sp.stage: Enter Candido, Lodovico, and Carolo. Lodovico other guests, and bride with prentices.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O gentlemen, so late, you're very welcome, pray sit down.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Carolo, didst ere see such a nest of caps?

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: Methinks
It's a most civil and most comely sight.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What does he ith' middle look like?

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: Troth like a spire steeple in a country village overpeering so many thatched houses.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: It's rather a long pike staff against so many bucklers without pikes; they sit for all the world like a pair of organs, and he's the tall great roaring pipe ith' midst.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What's that you laugh at, signiors?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Troth shall I tell you, and aloud I'll tell it,
We laugh to see (Yet laugh we not in scorn)
Amongst so many caps that long hat worn.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Mine is as tall a felt as any is this day in Milan, and therefore I love it, for the block was cleft out for my head, and fits me to a hair.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Indeed you are good observers, it shows strange.
But gentlemen, I pray neither contemn,
Nor yet deride a civil ornament;
I could build so much in the round caps praise,
That love this high roof, I this flat would raise.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Prithee sweet bridegroom do't.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: So all these guests will pardon me, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Thus then in the caps honour,
To every sex and state, both nature, time,
The country's laws, yea and the very clime
Do allot distinct habits, the spruce courtier
Jets up and down in silk: the warrior
Marches in buff, the clown plods on in grey:
But for these upper garments thus I say,
The seaman has his cap, pared without brim,
The gallants head is feathered, that fits him;
The soldier has his murrain, women ha' tires;
Beasts have their headpieces, and men ha' theirs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Each degree has his fashion, it's fit then,
One should be laid by for the citizen,
And that's the cap which you see swells not high,
For caps are emblems of humility;
It is a citizen's badge, and first was worn
By'th Romans; for when any bondman's turn
Came to be made a freeman: thus 'twas said,
He to the cap was called; that is, was made
Of Rome a freeman, but was first close shorn,
And so a citizen's hair is still short worn.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That close shaving made barbers a company,
And now every citizen uses it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Of geometric figures the most rare,
And perfectest are the circle and the square,
The city and the school much build upon
These figures, for both love proportion.
The city cap is round, the scholars square.
To show that government and learning are
The perfectest limbs i'th body of a state:
For without them, all's disproportionate.
If the cap had no honour, this might rear it,
The reverend fathers of the law do wear it.
It's light for summer, and in cold it sits
Close to the scull, a warm house for the wits;
It shows the whole face boldly, 'tis not made
as if a man to look on't were afraid,
Nor like a draper's shop with broad dark shed,
For he's no citizen that hides his head.
Flat caps as proper are to city gowns,
As to armours helmets, or to Kings their crowns.
Let then the city cap by none be scorned,
Since with it princes heads have been adorned.
If more the round caps honour you would know,
How would this long gown with this steeple show?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: most vile, most ugly.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Pray signior pardon me, 'twas done in jest.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: A cup of claret wine there.
Wine: yes forsooth, wine for the bride.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You ha' well set out the cap, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, that's flat.

sp.speaker: Long
sp.l: A health.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Since his cap's round, that
sp.stage: The bride hits the prentice on the lips.
sp.l: Shall go round. Be bare,
For in the caps praise all of you have share.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The bride's at cuffs.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O, peace I pray thee, thus far off I stand, I spied the error of my servants, she called for claret, and you filled out sack; that cup give me, 'tis for an old man's back, and not for hers. Indeed 'twas but mistaken, ask all these else.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: No faith, 'twas but mistaken.
Nay, she took it right enough.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Good Luke reach her that glass of claret.
Here, mistress Bride, pledge me there.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Now I'll none.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Look what your mistress ails.

sp.p: Nothing, sir, but about filling a wrong glass, a scurvy trick.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I pray you hold your tongue, my servant there tells me she is not well.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Step to her, step to her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A word with you: do ye hear? This wench (Your new wife) will take you down in your wedding shoes, unless you hang her up in her wedding garters.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: How, hang her in her garters?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Will you be a rame pigeon still? shall your back be like a tortoise shell, to let carts go over it, yet not to break? This she-cat will have more lives than your last puss had, and will scratch worse, and mouse you worse: look to't.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What would you have me do, sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What would I have you do? Swear, swagger, brawl, fling; for fighting it's no matter, we ha' had knocking pusses enough already; you know, that a woman was made of the rib of a man, and that rib was crooked. The moral of which is, that a man must from his beginning be crooked to his wife; be you like an orange to her, let her cut you never so fair, be you sour as vinegar; will you be ruled by me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: In any thing that's civil, honest, and just.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Have you ever a prentice's suit will fit me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I have the very same which myself wore.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I'll send my man for't within this half hour, and within this two hours I'll be your prentice: the hen shall not overcrow the cock, I'll sharpen your spurs.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It will be but some jest, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Only a jest: farewell, come Carolo:

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We'll take our leaves, sir, too.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Pray conceit not ill of my wife's sudden rising. This young knight, sir Lodovico, is deep seen in physic, and he tells me, the disease called the mother, hangs on my wife, it is a vehement heaving and beating of the stomach, and that swelling did with the pain thereof cramp up her arm, that hit his lips, and broke the glass: no harm, it was no harm.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: No, signior, none at all.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The straightest arrow may fly wide by chance.
But come, we'll close this brawl up in some dance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O my sweet husband, wert thou in thy grave, and art alive again? O welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Dost know me? my cloak prithee lay't up. Yes faith, my winding sheet was taken out of lavender, to be stuck with rosemary, I lacked but the knot here, or here; yet if I had had it, I should ha' made a wry mouth at the world like a plaice: but sweetest villain, I am here now, and I will talk with thee soon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And glad am I thou'rt here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Did these heels caper in shackles? A my little plump rogue, I'll bear up for all this, and fly high. Catzo Catzo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What sayest, what sayest? O brave fresh air, a pox on these grates and gingling of keys, and rattling of iron, I'll bear up, I'll fly high wench, hang toss.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Matheo, prithee make thy prison thy glass,
And in it view the wrinkles, and the scars,
By which thou wert disfigured, viewing them, mend them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll go visit all the mad rogues now, and the good roaring boys.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou dost not hear me?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes faith do I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou hast been in the hands of misery, and ta'en strong physic, prithee now be sound.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes. 'sfoot, I wonder how the inside of a tavern looks now. O when shall I bezzle, bizle?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay see, thou'rt thirsty still for poison, come, I will not have thee swagger.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Honest ape's face.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis that sharpened an axe to cut thy throat.
Good love, I would not have thee sell thy substance
And time (Worth all) in those damned shops of hell;
Those dicing houses, that stand never well,
but when they stand most ill, that four-squared sin
Has almost lodged us in the beggar's inn.
Besides (To speak which even my soul does grieve)
A sort of ravens have hung upon thy sleeve,
And fed upon thee: good Mat. (If you please) so base as
Scorn to spread wing amongst these;
By them thy fame is speckled, yet it shows
Clear amongst them; so crows are fair with crows.
Custom in sin, gives sin a lovely dye.
Blackness in mores is no deformity.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Bellafront, Bellafront, I protest to thee, I swear, as I hope my soul, I will turn over a new leaf, the prison I confess has bit me, the best man that sails in such a ship, may be lousy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: One knocks at door.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll be the porter: they shall see, a jail cannot hold a brave spirit, I'll fly high.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How wild is his behaviour! o, I fear
He's spoilt by prison, he's half damned comes there,
But I must sit all storms: when a full sail his
Fortunes spread, he loved me: being now poor,
I'll beg for him, and no wife can do more.
sp.stage: Enter Matheo, and Orlando like a servingman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come in prey, would you speak with me, sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is your name signior Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My name is signior Matheo.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is this gentlewoman your wife, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This gentlewoman is my wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: The destinies spin a strong and even thread of both your loves: the mother's own face, I ha' not forgotten that, I'm an old man, sir, and am troubled with a whoreson salt rheum , that I cannot hold my water. Gentlewoman, the last man I served was your father.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My father? any tongue that sounds his name,
Speaks music to me: welcome good old man.
How does my father? lives he? has he health?
How does my father? I so much do shame him,
So much do wound him, that I scarce dare name him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I can speak no more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How now old lad, what dost cry?

sp.speaker: Orl
sp.p: The rheum still, sir, nothing else; I should be well seasoned, for mine eyes lie in brine: look you, sir, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What is't my little white pate?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Troth, sir, I have a mind to serve your worship.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: To serve me? Troth, my friend, my fortunes are, as a man may say —

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Nay look you, sir, I know when all sins are old in us, and go upon crutches, that covetousness does but then lie in her cradle; 'tis not so with me. Lechery loves to dwell in the fairest lodging, and covetousness in the oldest buildings, that are ready to fall: but my white head, sir, is no inn for such a gossip. If a servingman at my years be not stored with biscuit enough, that has sailed about the world to serve him the voyage out of his life, and to bring him east-home; ill pity but all his days should be fasting days: I care not so much for wages, for I have scraped a handful of gold together; I have a little money, sir, which I would put into your worship's hands, not so much to make it more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No, no, you say well, thou sayest well; but I must tell you: how much is the money, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: About twenty pound, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Twenty pound? Let me see: that shall bring thee in, after ten per centum, per annum.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: No, no, no, sir, no; I cannot abide to have money engender: fie upon this silver lechery, fie; if I may have meat to my mouth, and rags to my back, and a flock-bed to snort upon, when I die, the longer liver take all.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A good old boy, i'faith, if thou servest me, thou shalt eat as I eat, drink as I drink, lie as I lie, and ride as I ride.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: That's if you have money to hire horses.

sp.speaker: Mat. and front
sp.p:
What dost thou think on't? This good old
lad here shall serve me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Alas, Matheo, wilt thou load a back
That is already broke?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Peace, pox on you, peace, there's a trick in't, I fly high, it shall be so, front. as I tell you: give me thy hand, thou shalt serve me i'faith: welcome: as for your money —

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Nay, look you sir, I have it here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pesh, keep it thyself, man, and then thou'rt sure 'tis safe.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Safe! and 'twere ten thousand ducats, your worship should be my cashkeeper; I have heard what your worship is, an excellent dunghill cock, to scatter all abroad: but I'll venture twenty pounds on's head.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And didst thou serve my worshipful father-in-law, signior Orlando Friscabaldo, that mad man once?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I served him so long, till he turned me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It's a notable chuff, I ha' not seen him many a day.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: No matter and you ne'er see him: it's an arrant grandy, a churl, and as damned a cutthroat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou villain, curb thy tongue, thou art a Judas,
To sell thy master's name to slander thus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Away ass, he speaks but truth, thy father is a —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And an old knave, there's more deceit in him then in sixteen pothecaries: it's a devil, thou mayst beg, starve, hang, damn; does he send thee so much as a cheese?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Or so much as a gammon of bacon,
He'll give it his dogs first.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A jail, a jail.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: A Jew, a Jew, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A dog.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: An English mastiff, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pox rot out his old stinking garbage.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Art not ashamed to strike an absent man thus?
Art not ashamed to let this vild dog bark,
And bite my father thus? I'll not endure it;
Out of my doors, base slave.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your doors! A vengeance? I shall live to cut that old rogues throat, for all you take his part thus.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: He shall live to see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: God's so my lord, your lordship is most welcome, I'm proud of this, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Was bold to see you.
Is that your wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll borrow her lip.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: With all my heart, my lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Who's this, I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My lord Hipollito: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Pacheco.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pacheco, fine name; thou seest, Pacheco, I keep company with no scoundrels, nor base fellows.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Came not my footman to you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I sent by him a diamond and a letter,
Did you receive them?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes my lord, I did.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Read you the letter?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O'er and o'er 'tis read.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And faith your answer?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now the time's not fit,
You see, my husbands here.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll now then leave you,
And choose mine hour; but ere I part away,
Hark, you remember I must have no nay.
Matheo, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A glass of wine.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not now, I'll visit you at other times.
You're come off well then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Excellent well, I thank your lordship: I owe you my life, my lord; and will pay my best blood in any service of yours.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I'll take no such dear payment, hark you Matheo, I know, the prison is a gulf, if money run low with you, my purse is yours: call for it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Faith my lord, I thank my stars, they send me down some; I cannot sink, so long as these bladders hold.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will not see your fortunes ebb, pray try.
To starve in full barns were fond modesty.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Open the door, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Drink this, and anon I pray thee give thy mistress this.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O noble spirit, if no worse guests here dwell,
My blue coat sits on my old shoulders well.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The only royal fellow, he's bounteous as the Indies,
What's that he said to thee, Bellafront?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I prithee good girl?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why I tell you nothing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Nothing? it's well: tricks, that I must be beholden to a scald hot-liver goatish gallant, to stand with my cap in my hand, and veil bonnet, when I ha' spread as lofty sails as himself, would I had been hanged. Nothing ▪ Pacheco, brush my cloak.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Where is't, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come, we'll fly high.
Nothing? there is a whore still in thine eye.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: My twenty pounds flies high, oh wretched woman,
This varlet's able to make Lucrece common.
sp.p: How now mistress? has my master died you into this sad colour?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fellow, be gone I pray thee; if thy tongue itch after talk so much, seek out thy master, thou'rt a fit instrument for him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Zounds, I hope he will not play upon me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Play on thee? no, you two will fly together,
Because you are roving arrows of one feather.
Would thou wouldst leave my house, thou ne'er shalt
Please, me weave thy nets ne'er so high,
thou shalt be but a spider in mine eye.
Thou'rt rank with poison, poison tempered well,
Is food for health; but thy black tongue doth swell
With venom, to hurt him that gave thee bread,
To wrong men absent, is to spurn the dead.
And so didst thou thy master, and my father.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You have small reason to take his part; for I have heard him say five hundred times, you were as arrant a whore as ever stiffened tiffany neckcloathes in water-starch upon a Saturday ith' afternoon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let him say worse, when for the earth's offence
Hot vengeance through the marble clouds is driven,
Is't fit earth shoot again those darts at heaven?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And so if your father call you whore, you'll not call him old knave: Friscabaldo, she carries thy mind up and down; she's thine own flesh, blood, and bone; troth mistress, to tell you true, the fireworks that ran from me upon lines against my good old master, your father, were but to try how my young master, your husband loved such squibs: but it's well known, I love your father as myself; I'll ride for him at midnight, run for you by owl-light; I'll die for him, drudge for you; I'll fly low, and I'll fly high (As my master says) to do you good, if you'll forgive me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am not made of marble: I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Nay, if you were made of marble, a good stone-cutter might cut you: I hope the twenty pound I delivered to my master, is in a sure hand.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: In a sure hand I warrant thee for spending.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I see my young master is a madcap, and a bonus socius, I love him well, mistress: yet as well as I love him, I'll not play the knave with you; look you, I could cheat you of this purse full of money; but I am an old lad, and I scorn to coney-catch: yet I ha' been dog at a coney in my time.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A purse, where hadst it?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: The gentleman that went away, whispered in mine care, and charged me to give it you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The lord Hipollito?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: Yes, if he be a lord, he gave it me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis all gold.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: 'Tis like so: it may be, he thinks you want money, and therefore bestows his alms bravely, like a lord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He thinks a silver net can catch the poor,
Here's bait to choke a nun, and turn her whore.
Wilt thou be honest to me?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: As your nails to your fingers, which I think never deceived you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou to this lord shalt go, commend me to him,
And tell him this, the town has held out long,
Because (Within) 'twas rather true, then strong.
To sell it now were base; say 'tis no hold
Built of weak stuff, to be blown up with gold.
He shall believe thee by this token, or this; if not, by this.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This is all.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Mine own girl still.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A star may shoot, not fall.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A star? nay, thou art more than the moon, for thou hast neither changing quarters, nor a man standing in thy circle with a bush of thorns. Is't possible the lord Hipollito, whose face is as civil as the outside of a dedicatory book, should be a muttonmonger? A poor man has but one ewe, and this grandy sheep-biter leaves whole flocks of fat wethers (Whom he may knock down) to devour this. I'll trust neither lord nor butcher with quick flesh for this trick; the cuckoo I see now sings all the year, though every man cannot hear him, but I'll spoil his notes; can neither love-letters, nor the devil's common picklocks (Gold) nor precious stones make my girl draw up her portcullis: hold out still, wench.
sp.l: All are not bawds (I see now) that keep doors,
Nor all good wenches that are marked for whores.
sp.stage: Enter Candido, Lodovico like a prentice.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Come, come, come, what do ye lack, sir? what
do ye lack, sir? what is't ye lack, sir? is not my worship well suited? did you ever see a gentleman better disguised?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Never, believe me, signior.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes: but when he has been drunk, there be prentices would make mad gallants, for they would spend all, and drink, and whore, and so forth; and I see we gallants could make mad prentices. How does thy wife like me? Nay, I must not be so saucy, than I spoil all: pray you how does my mistress like me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Well: for she takes you for a very simple fellow.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And they that are taken for such, are commonly the arrantest knaves: but to our comedy, come.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I shall not act it, chide you say, and fret,
And grow impatient: I shall never do't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Sblood, cannot you do as all the world does? counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Were I a painter, that should live by drawing nothing but pictures of an angry man, I should not earn my colours; I cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Remember you're a linen draper, and that if you give your wife a yard, she'll take an ell: give her not therefore a quarter of your yard, not a nail.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Say I should turn to ice, and nip her love now 'tis but in the blood.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, say she's nipped.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It will so overchange her heart with grief,
That like a cannon, when her sighs go off,
She in her duty either will recoil,
Or break in pieces and so die: her death,
By my unkindness might be counted murder.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Die? never, never; I do not bid you beat her, nor give her black eyes, nor pinch her sides: but cross her humours. Are not bakers arms the scales of justice? yet is not their bread light? and may not you I pray bridle her with a sharp bit, yet ride her gently?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Well, I will try your pills, do you your faithful service, and be ready still at a pinch to help me in this
part, or else I shall be out clean.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come, come, I'll prompt you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I'll call her forth now, shall I?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do, do, bravely.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Luke, I pray bid your mistress to come hither.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Luke, I pray bid your mistress to come hither.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Sirrah, bid my wife come to me: why, when?

sp.speaker: Luke.
sp.l: Presently, sir, she comes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: La you, there's the echo, she comes.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: What is your pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Marry wife,
I have intent, and (You see) this stripling here,
He bears good will and liking to my trade,
And means to deal in linen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes indeed, sir, I would deal in linen, if my mistress like me so well as I like her?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I hope to find him honest, pray good wife look that his bed and chamber be made ready.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: You're best to let him hire me for his maid? I look to his bed? look to't yourself.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Even so
I swear to you a great oath.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Swear, cry zounds.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I will not, go to wife, I will not,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That your great oath?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Swallow these gudgeons.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well said.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then fast, than you may choose.
You know at table
What tricks you played, swaggered, broke glasses! Fie,
Fie, fie, fie: and now before my prentice here
You make an ass of me; thou, (What shall I call thee?)

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Even what you will.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Call her arrant whore.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O fie, by no means, then she'll call me cuckold, sirrah, go look to'th shop: how does this show?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Excellent well, I'll go look to the shop, sir. Fine
cambrics, lawns, what do you lack.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: A cursed cow's milk I ha' drunk once before,
And 'twas so rank in taste, I'll drink no more.
Wife, I'll tame you.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: You may, sir, if you can,
But at a wrestling I have seen a fellow
Limbed like an ox, thrown by a little man.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: And so you'll throw me. Reach me (Knaves) a yard.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A yard for my master.

sp.speaker: 1. Prent.
sp.l: My master is grown valiant.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I'll teach you fencing tricks.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Rare, rare; a prize.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What will you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Marry, my good prentice, nothing but breathe my wife.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Breathe me with your yard?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, he'll but measure you out, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Since you'll needs fence, handle your weapon well,
For if you take a yard, I'll take an ell.
Reach me an ell.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: An ell for my mistress.
sp.p: Keep the laws of the noble science, sir, and measure weapons with her; your yard is a plain heathenish weapon; 'tis too short, she may give you a handful, and yet you'll not reach her.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Yet I ha' the longer arm, come fall to't roundly,
And spare not me (Wife) for I'll lay't on soundly.
If o'er husbands their wives will needs be masters,
We men will have a law to win't at wasters

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis for the breeches, is't not?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: For the breeches.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Husband I am for you, I'll not strike in jest.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: But will you sign to one request?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Let me give the first blow.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The first blow, wife, shall I? Prompt?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Let her have't.
If she strike hard, in to her, and break her pate.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: A bargain. Strike.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Then guard you from this blow,
For I play all at legs, but 'tis thus low.
Behold, I am such a cunning fencer grown,
I keep my ground, yet down I will be thrown
With the least blow you give me, I disdain
The wife that is her husband's sovereign.
She that upon your pillow first did rest,
They say, the breeches wore, which I detest.
The tax which she imposed upon you, I abate you,
If me you make your master, I shall hate you.
The world shall judge who offers fairest play;
You win the breeches, but I win the day.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Thou winst the day indeed, give me thy hand,
I'll challenge thee no more: my patient breast
Played thus the rebel, only for a jest:
Here's the rank rider that breaks colts, 'tis he
Can tame the mad folks, and cursed wives.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Who, your man?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My man? my master, though his head be bare,
But he's so courteous, he'll put off his hair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, if your service be so hot, a man cannot keep his hair on, I'll serve you no longer.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Is this your schoolmaster?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes faith, wench, I taught him to take thee down: I hope thou canst take him down without teaching; you ha' got the conquest, and you both are friends.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Bear witness else.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My prenticeship then ends.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: For the good service you to me have done,
I give you all your years.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I thank you master.
I'll kiss my mistress now, that she may say,
My man was bound, and free all in one day.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: From whom sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: From a poor gentlewoman, madam, whom I serve.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: And what's your business?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: This, madam: my poor mistress has a waste piece of ground, which is her own by inheritance, and left to her by her mother; there's a lord now that goes about, not to take it clean from her, but to enclose it to himself, and to join it to a piece of his lordships.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: What would she have me do in this?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: No more, madam, but what one woman should do for another in such a case. My honourable lord, your husband would do any thing in her behalf, but she had rather put herself into your hands, because you (A woman) may do more with the Duke your father.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Where lies this land?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Within a stone's cast of this place; my mistress, I think, would be content to let him enjoy it after her decease, if that would serve his turn, so my master would yield too: but she cannot abide to hear that the lord should meddle with it in her life time.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: Is she then married? why stirs not her husband in it?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Her husband stirs in it under hand: but because the other is a great rich man, my master is loath to be seen in it too much.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Let her in writing draw the cause at large:
And I will move the Duke.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: 'Tis set down, madam, here in black and white already: work it so, madam, that she may keep her own without disturbance, grievance, molestation, or meddling of any other; and she bestows this purse of gold on your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Old man, I'll plead for her, but take no fees:
Give lawyers them, I swim not in that flood,
I'll touch no gold, till I have done her good.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I would all proctors clerks were of your mind, I should law more amongst them than I do then; here, madam, is the survey, not only of the manor itself, but of
the grange house, with every meadow pasture, ploughland, coney-burrow, fishpond, hedge, ditch, and bush that stands in it.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: My husband's name, and hand and seal at arms to a love-letter? Where hadst thou this writing?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: From the foresaid party, madam, that would keep the foresaid land out of the foresaid lords fingers.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: My lord turned ranger now?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: You're a good huntress, lady, you ha' found your game already; your lord would fain be a ranger, but my mistress requests you to let him run a course in your own park, if you'll not do't for love, than do't for money; she has no white money, but there's gold, or else she prays you to ring him by this token, and so you shall be sure his nose will not be rooting other men's pastures.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: This very purse was woven with mine own hands,
This diamond on that very night, when he
Untied my virgin girdle, gave I him:
And must a common harlot share in mine?
Old man, to quit thy pains, take thou the gold.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Not I, madam, old serving-men want no money.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Cupid himself was sure his secretary,
These lines are even the arrows love let flies,
The very ink dropped out of Venus' eyes.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: I do not think, madam, but he fetched off some poet or other for those lines, for they are perilous hawks to fly at wenches.

sp.speaker: Infae
sp.l: Here's honeyed poison, to me he ne'er thus writ,
But lust can set a double edge on wit.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: Nay, that's true, madam, a wench will whet any thing, if it be not too dull.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Oaths, promises, preferments, jewels, gold,
What snares should break, if all these cannot hold?
What creature is thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: One of those creatures that are contrary to man; a woman.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: What manner of woman?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A little tiny woman, lower than your ladyship by head and shoulders, but as mad a wench as ever unlaced a petticoat: these things should I indeed have delivered to my lord your husband.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: They are delivered better: why should she send back these things?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Ware, ware, there's knavery.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Strumpets like cheating gamesters will not win
At first: these are but baits to draw him in.
How might I learn his hunting hours?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: The Irish footman can tell you all his hunting hours, the park he hunts in, the doe he would strike, that Irish shackatory beats the bush for him, and knows all; he brought that letter, and that ring; he is the carrier.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: Knowest thou what other gifts have passed between them?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Little s. Patrick knows all.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Him Ise examine presently.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Not whilst I am here, sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Be gone then, and what lies in me command.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: Come hither sirrah, how much cost those satins, and cloth of silver, which my husband sent by you to a low gentlewoman yonder?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Faat satins? faat silvers, faat low gentlefolks? dow pratest dow knowest not what, yfaat la.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: She there, to whom you carried letters.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: By dis hand and bod dow sayest true, if I did so, o how? I know not a letter a de book yfaat la.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: Did your lord never send you with a ring, sir, set with a diamond?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Never, sa crees sa me, never; he may run at a tousand rings yfaat, and I never hold his stirrup, till he leap into de saddle. By s. Patrick, madam, I never touch my lords diamond, nor ever had to do, yfaat la, with any of his precious stones.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Are you so close, you bawd, you pandering slave?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How now? why Infaelice? what's your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Out of my sight, base varlet, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Away you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Slawne loot, fare de well, fare de well. Ah marragh frofat boddah breen.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What, grown a fighter? prithee what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: If you'll needs know, it was about the clock: how works the day, my lord, (Pray) by your watch?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Lest you cuff me, I'll tell you presently: I am near two.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: How, two? I am scarce at one.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: One of us then goes false.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Then sure 'tis you,
Mine goes by heaven's dial, (The sun) and it goes true.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I think (Indeed) mine runs somewhat too fast.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Set it to mine (At one) then.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: One? 'tis past:
'Tis past one by the sun.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Faith then belike,
Neither your clock nor mine does truly strike,
And since it is uncertain which goes true,
Better be false at one, then false at two.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You're very pleasant, madam.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Yet not merry.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why Infaelice, what should make you sad?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Nothing my lord, but my false watch, pray tell me,
You see, my clock, or yours is out of frame,
Must we upon the workman lay the blame,
Or on yourselves that keep them?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith on both.
He may by knavery spoil them, we by sloth,
But why talk you all riddle thus? I read
Strange comments in those margins of your looks:
Your cheeks of late are (Like bad printed books)
So dimly charactered, I scarce can spell,
one line of love in them. Sure all's not well.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: All is not well indeed, my dearest lord,
Lock up thy gates of hearing, that no sound
Of what I speak may enter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Or if my own tongue must myself betray,
Count it a dream, or turn thine eyes away,
And think me not thy wife.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why do you kneel?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.p: Earth is sin's cushion: when the sick soul feels herself growing poor, than she turns beggar, cries and kneels for help; Hipollito (For husband I dare not call thee) I have stolen that jewel of my chaste honour (Which was only thine) and given it to a slave.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: On thy pillow adultery and lust have slept, thy groom
Hath climbed the unlawful tree, and plucked the sweets,
A villain hath usurped a husband's sheets.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, who, (A cuckold) who?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: This Irish footman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Worse than damnation, a wild kern, a frog, a dog: whom I'll scarce spurn. Longed you for shamrock? were it my father's father (Heart) I'll kill him, although I take him on his deathbed gasping 'twixt heaven and hell; a shag-haired cur? Bold strumpet, why hangest thou on me? thinkst I'll be a bawd to a whore, because she's noble?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: I beg but this,
Set not my shame out to the world's broad eye,
Yet let thy vengeance (Like my fault) soar high,
So it be in darkened clouds.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Darkened! my horns
Cannot be darkened, nor shall my revenge.
A harlot to my slave? the act is base,
Common, but foul, so shall thy disgrace:
Could not I feed your appetite? o women
You were created angels, pure and fair;
But since the first fell, tempting devils you are,
you should be men's bliss, but you prove their rods.
Were there no women, men might live like gods:
You ha' been too much down already, rise,
Get from my sight, and henceforth shun my bed,
I'll with no strumpet's breath be poisoned.
As for your Irish leprechaun, that spirit
Whom by preposterous charms thy lust hath raised
In a wrong circle, him I'll damn more black
Than any tyrant's soul.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Hipollito?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Tell me, didst thou bait hawks to draw him to thee, or did he bewitch thee?

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: The slave did woo me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Two woes in that screech-owl's language? O who would trust your cork-heeled sex? I think to sate your lust, you would love a horse, a bear, a croaking toad, so your hot itching veins might have their bound, than the wild Irish dart was thrown. Come, how? the manner of this fight.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: 'Twas thus, he gave me this battery first. O I
Mistake, believe me, all this in beaten gold:
Yet I held out, but at length this was charmed.
What? change your diamond wench, the act is base,
Common, but foul, so shall not your disgrace:
Could not I feed your appetite? O men,
You were created angels, pure and fair,
But since the first fell, worse than devils you are.
You should our shields be, but you prove our rods.
Were there no men, women might live like gods.
Guilty my lord?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yes, guilty my good lady.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Nay, you may laugh, but henceforth shun my bed,
With no whores leavings I'll be poisoned.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O'erreached so finely? 'tis the very diamond
And letter which I sent: this villainy
Some spider closely weaves, whose poisoned bulk
I must let forth. Who's there without?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: My lord calls.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Send me the footman.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Call the footman to my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It can be no man else, that Irish Judas,
Bred in a country where no venom prospers,
But in the nation's blood hath thus betrayed me.
Slave, get you from your service.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.l: Faat meanest thou by this now?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Question me not, nor tempt my fury, villain,
Couldst thou turn all the mountains in the land,
To hills of gold, and to give me; here thou stayest not.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.l: I faat, I care not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Prate not, but get thee gone, I shall send else.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Ay, do prithee, I had rather have thee make a scabbard of my guts, and let out all de Irish puddings in my poor belly, den to be a false knave to de I faat, I will never see dine own sweet face more. A mawhid dear a gra, fare de well, fare de well, I will go steal Cowes again in Ireland.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He's damned that raised this whirlwind, which hath blown
sp.l: Into her eyes this jealousy: yet I'll on,
I'll on, stood armed devils staring in my face,
To be pursued in flight, quickens the race,
Shall my blood streams by a wife's lust be barred?
Fond woman, no: iron grows by strokes more hard,
Lawless desires are seas scorning all bounds,
Or sulphur which being rammed up, more confounds,
Struggling with mad men, madness nothing tames,
Winds wrestling with great fires, incense the flames.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How now, what ails your master?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Has taken a younger brother's purge, forsooth, and that works with him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where is his cloak and rapier?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He has given up his cloak, and his rapier is bound to the peace: if you look a little higher, you may see that another hath entered into hatband for him too. Six and four have put him into this sweat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where's all his money?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: 'Tis put over by exchange: his doublet was going to be translated, but for me: if any man would ha' lent but half a ducat on his beard, the hair of it had stuffed a pair of breeches by this time; I had but one poor penny, and that I was glad to niggle out, and buy a holly-wand to grace him thorough the street. As hap was, his boots were on, and then I dustied, to make people think he had been riding, and I had run by him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O me, how does my sweet Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O rogue, of what devilish stuff are these dice made off? of the parings of the devil's corns of his toes, that they run thus damnably.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I prithee vex not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: If any handicraft's man was ever suffered to keep shop in hell, it will be a dice-maker; he's able to undo more souls than the devil; I played with mine own dice, yet lost. Ha you any money?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Las I ha' none.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Must have money, must have some, must have a cloak, and rapier, and things: will you go set your lime-twigs, and get me some birds, some money?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What lime-twigs should I set?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You will not then? Must have cash and pictures: do ye hear, (Frailty) shall I walk in a Plymouth cloak, (That's to say) like a rogue, in my hose and doublet, and a crabtree cudgel in my hand, and you swim in your satins? must have money, come.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Is't bedtime, master, that you undo my mistress?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Undo me? Yes, yes, at these riflings
I have been too often.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Help to flea, Pacheco.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Flaying call you it?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll pawn you by'th lord, to your very eyebrows.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart, since heaven will have me poor,
As good he drowned at sea, as drowned at shore.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Why hear you, sir? i'faith do not make away her gown.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O it's summer, it's summer; your only fashion for a woman now, is to be light, to be light.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Why, pray sir, employ some of that money you have of mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thine? I'll starve first, I'll beg first; when I touch a penny of that, let these fingers ends rot.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: So they may, for that's passed touching. I saw my twenty pounds fly high.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Knowest thou never a damned broker about the city?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Damned broker? yes, five hundred.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The gown stood me in above twenty ducats, borrow ten of it, cannot live without silver.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I'll make what I can of it, sir, I'll be your broker,
But not your damned broker: o thou scurvy knave,
What makes a wife turn whore, but such a slave?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How now little chick, what ailest, weeping
sp.p: For a handful of tailor's shreds? pox on them, are there not silks enough at mercers?

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.l: I care not for gay feathers, I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What dost care for then? why dost grieve?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why do I grieve? A thousand sorrows strike
At one poor heart, and yet it lives. Matheo,
Thou art a gamester, prithee throw at all,
Set all upon one cast, we kneel and pray,
And struggle for life, yet must be cast away.
Meet misery quickly then, split all, sell all,
And when thou hast sold all, spend it, but I beseech thee
Build not thy mind on me to coin thee more,
To get it wouldst thou have me play the whore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Twas your profession before I married you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Umh? it was indeed: if all men should be branded
For sins long since laid up, who could be saved?
The quarter day's at hand, how will you do
To pay the rent, Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why? do as all of our occupation do against quarter days; break up house, remove, shift your lodgings, pox a your quarters.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Where's this gallant?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Signior Lodovico? how does my little mirror of knighthood? this is kindly done i'faith: welcome by my troth.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And how dost, frolic? Save you fair lady. Thou lookest smug and bravely, noble Mat.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Drink and feed, laugh and lie warm.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is this thy wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A poor gentlewoman, sir, whom I make use of a nights.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pay custom to your lips, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Borrow some shells of him, some wine, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'll send for't then i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You send for't? Some wine I prithee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I ha' no money.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Sblood, nor I: what wine love you, signior?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Here, or I'll not stay, I protest; trouble the gentlewoman too much?
sp.l: And what news flies abroad, Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Troth, none. O signior, we ha' been merry in our days.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And no doubt shall again.
The divine powers never shoot darts at men
Mortal, to kill them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You say true.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why should we grieve at want?
Say the world made thee her minion, that
thy head lay in her lap, and that she danced thee
On her wanton knee, she could but give thee a whole
World: that's all, and that all's nothing; the world's
Greatest part cannot fill up one corner of thy heart.
Say, the three corners were all filled, alas!
Of what art thou possessed, a thin blown glass:
Such as by boys is puffed into the air.
Were twenty kingdoms thine, thou'dst live in care:
Thou couldst not sleep the better, nor live longer,
Nor merrier be, nor healthfuller, nor stronger.
If then thou wantest, thus make that want thy pleasure,
No man wants all things, nor has all in measure.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I am the most wretched fellow: sure some left-handed priest christened me, I am so unlucky: I am never out of one puddle or another, still falling.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fill out wine to my little finger.
With my heart i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thanks, good Matheo.
To your own sweet self.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: All the broker's hearts, sir, are made of flint, I can with all my knocking, strike but six sparks of fire out of them, here's six ducats, if you'll take them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Give me them: an evil conscience gnaw them all, moths and plagues hang upon their lousy wardrobes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is this your man, Matheo? An old servingman.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: You may give me tother half too, sir:
That's the beggar.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What haste there, gold?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A sort of rascals are in my debt, (God knows what) and they feed me with bits, with crumbs, a pox choke them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A word, Matheo: be not angry with me,
Believe it that I know the touch of time,
And can part copper (Though it be gilded o'er)
From the true gold: the sails which thou dost spread,
would show well, if they were not borrowed.
The sound of thy low fortunes drew me hither,
I give myself unto thee, prithee use me,
I will bestow on you a suit of satin,
And all things else to fit a gentleman,
Because I love you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thanks, good noble knight.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Call on me when you please,
Till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hast angled? hast cut up this fresh salmon?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Wouldst have me be so base?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It's base to steal, it's base to be a whore:
Thou'lt be more base, I'll make thee keep a door.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I hope he will not sneak away with all the money, will he?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou seest he does.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Nay then it's well. I set my brains upon an upright last; though my wits be old, yet they are like a withered pippin, wholesome. Look you, mistress, I told him I had but six ducats of the (Knave) Broker, but I had eight, and kept these two for you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have given him all.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: What, to fly high?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Like waves, my misery drives on misery.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Sell his wife's clothes from her back? does any poulterer's wife pull chickens alive? He riots all abroad, wants all at home; he dices, whores, swaggers, swears, cheats, borrows, pawns: I'll give him hook and line, a little more for all this.
sp.l: Yet sure i'th end he'll delude all my hopes,
And show me a French trick danced on the ropes.
sp.stage: Enter at one door Lodovico and Carolo; at another bots, and mistress horseleech; Candido and his wife appear in the shop.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hist, hist, lieutenant bots, how dost, man?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Whither are you ambling, madam horseleech?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.l: About worldly profit, sir: how do your worships?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: We want tools, gentlemen, to furnish the trade: they wear out day and night, they wear out till no mettle be left in their back; we hear of two or three new wenches are come up with a carrier, and your old goshawk here is flying at them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And faith, what flesh have you at home?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Ordinary dishes, by my troth, sweet men, there's few good i'th city; I am as well furnished as any, and though I say it, as well customed.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: We have meats of all sorts of dressing; we have stewed meat for your Frenchmen, pretty light picking meat for your Italian, and that which is rotten roasted, for don Spaniardo.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A pox on't.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: We have poulterers ware for your sweet bloods, as dove, chicken, duck, teal, woodcock, and so forth: and butcher's meat for the citizen: yet muttons fall very bade this year.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Stay, is not that my patient linen draper yonder, and my fine young smug mistress, his wife?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sirrah grannam, I'll give thee for thy fee twenty crowns, if thou canst but procure me the wearing of yond velvet cap.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: You'd wear another thing besides the cap. You're a wag.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: Twenty crowns? we'll share, and I'll be your pulley to draw her on.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do't presently; we'll ha' some sport.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Wheel you about, sweet men: do you see, I'll cheapen wares of the man, whilst bots is doing with his wife.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: To't: if we come into the shop to do you grace, we'll call you madam.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Pox a your old face, give it the badge of all scurvy faces, a masque.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What is't you lack, gentlewoman? Cambric or lawns, or fine hollands? Pray draw near, I can sell you a pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Some cambric for my old lady.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Cambric? you shall, the purest thread in Milan.

sp.speaker: Lod. and Car.
sp.l: Save you, signior Candido.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How does my noble master? how my fair mistress?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: My worshipful good servant, view it well, for 'tis both fine and even.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, madam, though masked, I thought it should be you by your man. Pray signior, show her the best, for she commonly deals for good ware.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then this shall fit her, this is for your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: A word, I pray, there is a waiting gentlewoman of my ladies: her name is Ruyna, says she's your kinswoman, and that you should be one of her ants.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: One of her ants? troth sir, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: If it please you to bestow the poor labour of your legs at any time, I will be your convoy thither?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am a snail, sir, seldom leave my house, if't please her to visit me, she shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Bots.
