sp.p: Do you hear? the naked troth is: my lady hath a young knight, her son, who loves you, you're made, if you lay hold upon't: this jewel he sends you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I return his love and jewel with scorn; let go my hand, or I shall call my husband. You are an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, will she do?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Do? they shall all do if bots sets upon them once, she was as if she had professed the trade, squeamish at first, at last I showed her this jewel, said, a knight sent it her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is't gold, and right stones?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Copper, copper, I go a fishing with these baits.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She nibbled, but would not swallow the hook, because the cunger-head her husband was by: but she bids the gentleman name any afternoon, and she'll meet him at her garden house, which I know.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is this no lie now?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Damn me if —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O prithee stay there.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: The twenty crowns, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Before he has his work done? but on my knightly word, he shall pay't thee.
sp.stage: Enter Astolpho, Beraldo, Fontinell, and the Irish footman.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: I thought thou hadst been gone into thine own country.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.l: No faat la, I cannot go dis four or tree days.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Look thee, yonder's the shop, and that's the man himself.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.p: Thou shalt but cheapen, and do as we told thee, to put a jest upon him, to abuse his patience.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: I faat, I doubt my pate shall be knocked: but sa crees sa me, for your shakes, I will run to any linen draper in hell, come preddy.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Save you gallants.

sp.speaker: Lod. and Car.
sp.l: O, well met!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: You'll give no more you say? I cannot take it.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.l: Truly I'll give no more.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: It must not fetch it. What would you have, sweet gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: Nay, here's the customer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The garden-house you say? we'll boult out your roguery.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will but lay these parcels by — my men are all at customhouse unloading wares, if cambric you would deal in, there's the best, all Milan cannot sample it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Do you hear? 1. 2. 3. 'sfoot, there came in 4. Gallants, sure your wife is slipped up, and the 4th. man I hold my life, is grafting your warden tree.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: you gentlemen are full of jest.
If she be up, she's gone some wares to show,
I have above as good wares as below.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Have you so? nay then —

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Now gentlemen, is't cambrics?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.l: I predee now let me have de best wares.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What's that he says, pray 'Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Marry he says we are like to have the best wares.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: The best wares? all are bad, yet wares do good, and like to surgeons, let sick kingdom's blood.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Faat a devil pratest tow so, a pox on dee, I prithee let me see some holland, to make linen shirts, for fear my body be lousy.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Indeed I understand no word he speaks.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Marry, he says, that at the siege in holland there was much bawdry used among the soldiers, though they were lousy.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It may be so, that's likely, true indeed,
In every garden, sir, does grow that weed.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Pox on de gardens, and de weeds, and de fool's cap dear, and de clouts; hear? dost make a hobby-horse of me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: O fie, he has torn de cambric.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: It frets me to the soul.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: So dost not me.
My customers do oft for remnants call,
These are two remnants now, no loss at all.
But let me tell you, were my servants here,
It would ha' cost more. — thank you gentlemen,
I use you well, pray know my shop again.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha; come, come, let's go, let's go.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How am I suited, front? am I not gallant, ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, sir, you are suited well.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Exceeding passing well, and to the time.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The tailor has played his part with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And I have played a gentleman's part with my tailor, for I owe him for the making of it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And why did you so, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
To keep the fashion; it's your only fashion now of your best rank of gallants, to make their tailors wait
for their money, neither were it wisdom indeed to pay them upon the first edition of a new suit: for commonly the suit is owing for, when the linings are worn out, and there's no reason then, that the tailor should be paid before the mercer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is this the suit the knight bestowed upon you?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is the suit, and I need not shame to wear it, for better men than I would be glad to have suits bestowed on them. It's a generous fellow, — but — pox on him — we whose pericranions are the very limbecks and stillatories of good wit, and fly high, must drive liquor out of stale gaping oysters. Shallow knight, poor squire Tinacheo: I'll make a wild captain of forty such: hang him, he's an ass, he's always sober.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This is your fault to wound your friends still.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No faith, front, Lodovico is a noble Slavonian: it's more rare to see him in a woman's company, then for a Spaniard to go into England, and to challenge the English fencers there. — one knocks, — see — la, fa, sol, la, fa, la, rustle in silks and satins: there's music in this, and a taffety petticoat, it make both fly high, — Catzo.
sp.stage: Enter Bellafront, after her Orlando like himself, with four men after him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Matheo? 'tis my father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ha, father? It's no matter, he finds no tattered prodigals here.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Is not the door good enough to hold your blue coats? away, knaves. Wear not your clothes threadbare at knees for me; beg heaven's blessing, (Not mine.) O cry your worship mercy, sir, was somewhat bold to talk to this gentlewoman, your wife here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A poor gentlewoman, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Stand not, sir, bore to me; I ha' read oft
That serpents who creep low, belch ranker poison
That winged dragons do, that fly aloft.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If it offend you, sir? 'tis for my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Your pleasure be't, sir; umh, is this your palace?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, and our kingdom, for 'tis our content.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: It's a very poor kingdom then; what, are all your subjects gone a sheepshearing? not a maid? not a man? not so much as a cat? you keep a good house belike, just like one of your profession, every room with bare walls, and a half-headed bed to vault upon (As all your bawdy-houses are.) Prey who are your upholsters? O, the spider. I see, they bestow hangings upon you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Bawdy-house? Zounds sir —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O sweet Matheo, peace. Upon my knees
I do beseech you, sir, not to arraign me
For sins, which heaven, I hope, long since hath pardoned.
Those flames (Like lightning flashes) are so spent,
The heat no more remains, then where ships went,
Or where birds cut the air, the print remains.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pox on him, kneel to a dog?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She that's a whore,
Lives gallant, fares well, is not (Like me) poor,
I ha' now as small acquaintance with that sin,
As if I had never known it; that, never been.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: No acquaintance with it? what maintains thee then? how dost live then? has thy husband any lands? any rends coming in, any stock going, any ploughs jogging, any ships sailing? hast thou any wares to turn, so much as to get a single penny by? yes, thou hast ware to sell, knaves are thy chapmen, and thy shop is hell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: So sir, I do hear, sir, more of you than you dream I do.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You fly a little too high, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Why, sir, too high?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I ha' suffered your tongue, like a bard Cater tra, to run all this while, and ha' not stopped it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Well, sir, you talk like a gamester.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: If you come to bark at her, because she's a poor rogue; look you, here's a fine path, sir, and there, there the door.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your blue coats stay for you, sir.
I love a good honest roaring boy, and so —

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: That's the devil.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir, sir, I'll ha' no Jove's in my house to thunder avant: she shall live and be maintained, when you, like a keg of musty sturgeon, shall stink. Where? in your coffin. How? be a musty fellow, and lousy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I know she shall be maintained, but how? she like a quean, thou like a knave; she like a whore, thou like a thief.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thief? Zounds thief?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good dearest Mat. — father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox on you both, I'll not be braved: new satin scorns to be put down with bare bawdy velvet. Thief?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I thief, thou'rt a murderer, a cheater, a whoremonger, a pothunter, a borrower, a beggar —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dear father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: An old ass, a dog, a churl, a chuff, an usurer, a villain, a moth, a mangy mule, with an old velvet foot-cloth on his back, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Varlet, for this I'll hang thee.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha, ha, alas.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thou keepest a man of mine here, under my nose.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Under thy beard.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: As arrant a smell-smock, for an old muttonmonger, as thyself.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, as yourself.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: As arrant a purse-take. as ever cried, stand, yet a good fellow, I confess, and valiant, but he'll bring thee to'th gallows; you both have robbed of late two poor country pedlars.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How's this? how's this? dost thou fly high? rob pedlars? bear witness front, rob pedlars? my man and I a thief?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O, sir, no more.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I knave, two pedlars, hue and cry is up, warrants are out, and I shall see thee climb a ladder.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: And come down again as well as a bricklayer, or a tiler. How the vengeance knows he this? If I be hanged, I'll tell the people I married old Friscabaldo's daughter, I'll frisco you, and your old carcase.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Tell what thou canst; if I stay here longer, I shall be hanged too, for being in thy company; therefore, as I found you, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Kneel, and get money of him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A knave and a quean, a thief and a strumpet, a couple of beggars, a brace of baggages.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Hang upon him. Ay, ay, sir, fare you well; we are so: follow close — we are beggars — in satin — to him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is this your comfort, when so many years
You ha' left me frozen to death?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Freeze still, starve still.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, so I shall: I must: I must and will.
If as you say I'm poor, relieve me then,
Let me not sell my body to base men.
You call me strumpet, heaven knows I am none:
Your cruelty may drive me to be one:
Let not that sin be yours, let not the shame
Of common whore live longer than my name.
That cunning bawd (Necessity) night and day
Plots to undo me; drive that hag away,
Lest being at lowest ebb, as now I am,
I sink for ever.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Lowest ebb, what ebb?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: So poor, that (Though to tell it be my shame)
I am not worth a dish to hold my meat;
I am yet poorer, I want bread to eat.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: It's not seen by your cheeks.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I think she has read an homely to tickle to the old rogue.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Want bread? there's satin: bake that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Sblood, make pasties of my clothes?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A fair new cloak, stew that; an excellent gilt rapier.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Will you eat that, sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I could feast ten good fellows with those hangers.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The pox you shall.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I shall not (Till thou beggest,) think thou art poor;
And when thou beggest, I'll feed thee at my door,
As I feed dogs, (With bones) till then beg,
Borrow, pawn, steal, and hang, turn bawd.
When thou'rt no whore, my heartstrings sure
Would crack, were they strained more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is your father, your damned — confusion light upon all the generation of you; he can come bragging hither with four white herrings (At's tail) in blue coats without roes in their bellies, but I may starve ere he give me so much as a cob.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What tell you me of this? alas.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Go trot after your dad, do you capitulate, I'll pawn not for you, I'll not steal to be hanged for such an hypocritical close common harlot: away, you dog — brave i'faith! Uds foot, give me some meat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Goodman slave, my man too, is galloped to the devil a'th' tother side: Pacheco, I'll checo you. Is this your dad's day? England (They say) is the only hell for horses, and only paradise for women: pray get you to that paradise, because you're called an honest whore; there they live none but honest whores with a pox: marry here in our city, all our sex are but foot-cloth nags: the master no sooner lights, but the man leaps into the saddle.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Will you sit down I pray, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I could tear (By'th lord) his flesh, and eat his midriff in salt, as I eat this: — must I choke — my father Friscabaldo, I shall make a pitiful hog-louse of you Orlando, if you fall once into my fingers — here's the sauorest
meat: I ha' got a stomach with chasing. What rogue should tell him of those two pedlars? A plague choke him, and gnaw him to the bare bones: come fill.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou sweatest with very anger, good sweet, vex not, alas, 'tis no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Where didst buy this mutton? I never felt better ribs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A neighbour sent it me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ha, neighbour? foh, my mouth stinks, you whore, do you beg victuals for me? Is this satin doublet to be bombasted with broken meat?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: What will you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Beat out the brains of a beggarly —

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Beat out an ass's head of your own; away, mistress. 'zounds, do but touch one hair of her, and I'll so quilt your cap with old iron, that your coxcomb shall ache the worse these seven years for't: does she look like a roasted rabbit, that you must have the head for the brains?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ha, ha: go out of my doors, you rogue, away, four marks trudge.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Four marks? no, sir, my twenty pound that you ha' made fly high, and I am gone.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Must I be fed with chippings? you're best get a clapdish, and say you're proctor to some spittle-house. Where hast thou been, Pacheco? come hither my little turkey-cock.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I cannot abide, sir, to see a woman wronged, not I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sirrah, here was my father-in-law today.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Pish, then you're full of crowns.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Hang him, he would ha' thrust crowns upon me, to have fallen in again, but I scorn cast-clothes, or any man's gold.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: But mine: how did he brook that (Sir?)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O: swore like a dozen of drunken tinkers; at last growing foul in words, he and four of his men drew upon me, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: In your house? would I had been by.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I made no more ado, but fell to my old lock, and so thrashed my blue coats, and old crabtree-face my father-in-law, and then walked like a lion in my grate.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O noble master!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sirrah, he could tell me of the robbing the two pedlars, and that warrants are out for us both.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Good, sir, I like not those crackers.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Crack halter, wilt set thy foot to mine?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: How, sir? at drinking.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: We'll pull that old crow my father: rob thy master. I know the house, thou the servants: the purchase is rich, the plot to get it easy, the dog will not part from a bone.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Plucked out of his throat then: I'll snarl for one, if this can bite.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Say no more, say no more, old coal, meet me anon at the sign of the shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And dost hear, man? — the shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thou'rt at the shipwreck now, and like a swimmer
Bold (But unexpert) with those waves dost play,
Whose dalliance (Whorelike) is to cast thee away.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: And here's another vessel, (Better fraught,
But as ill maned) her sinking will be wrought,
If rescue come not: like a man of war
I'll therefore bravely out: somewhat I'll do,
And either save them both, or perish too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is my fate to be bewitched by those eyes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fate? your folly.
Why should my face thus mad you? Alas, those colours
Are wound up long ago, which beauty spread,
The flowers that once grew here, are withered.
You turned my black soul white, made it look new,
And should I sin, it ne'er should be with you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your hand, I'll offer you fair play: when first
We met i'th lists together, you remember
You were a common rebel; with one parley
I won you to come in.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll try
If now I can beat down this chastity
With the same ordnance; will you yield this fort,
If with the power of argument now (As then)
I get of you the conquest: as before
I turned you honest, now to turn you whore,
By force of strong persuasion?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you can,
I yield.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The alarm's struck up: I'm your man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A woman gives defiance.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Begin:
'Tis a brave battle to encounter sin.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You men that are to fight in the same war,
To which I'm pressed, and plead at the same bar,
To win a woman, if you would have me speed,
Send all your wishes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No doubt you're heard, proceed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: To be a harlot, that you stand upon,
The very name's a charm to make you one.
Harlot was a dame of so divine
And ravishing touch, that she was concubine
To an English King: her sweet bewitching eye
Did the King's heartstrings in such love-knots tie,
That even the coyest was proud when she could hear
Men say, behold; another harlot there;
And after her all women that were fair
Were harlots called, as to this day some are:
Besides her dalliance, she so well does mix,
That she's in Latin called the meretrix.
Thus for the name; for the profession, this,
who lives in bondage, lives laced, the chief bliss
This world below can yield, is liberty:
And who (Than whores) with looser wings dare fly?
As Juno's proud bird spreads the fairest tail,
So does a strumpet hoist the loftiest sail.
She's no man's slave; (Men are her slaves) her eye
Moves not on wheels screwed up with jealousy.
She (Horsed, or coached) does merry journeys make,
Free as the sun in his gilt zodiac:
As bravely does she shine, as fast she's driven,
But stays not long in any house of heaven:
But shifts from sign, to sign, her amorous prizes
More rich being when she's down, then when she rises.
In brief, gentlemen haunt them, soldiers fight for them,
Few men but know them, few or none abhor them:
Thus (For sport's sake) speak I, as to a woman,
Whom (As the worst ground) I would turn to common:
But you I would enclose for mine own bed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: So should a husband be dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Dishonoured? not a whit: to fall to one
(Besides your husband) is to fall to none,
For one no number is.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Faith, should you take
One in your bed, would you that reckoning make?
'Tis time you sound retreat.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Say, have I won,
Is the day ours?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The battle's but half done,
None but yourself have yet sounded alarms,
Let us strike too, else you dishonour arms.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: If you can win the day,
The glory's yours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To prove a woman should not be a whore,
When she was made, she had one man, and no more,
Yet she was tied to laws then, for (Oven then)
'Tis said, she was not made for men, but man.
Anon, t'increase earth's brood, the law was varied,
men should take many wives: and though they married
According to that act, yet 'tis not known,
But that those wives were only tied to one.
New parliaments were since: for now one woman
Is shared between three hundred, nay she's common;
Common? as spotted leopards, whom for sport
Men hunt, to get the flesh, but care not for't.
So spread they nets of gold, and tune their calls,
To inchant silly women to take falls:
Swearing they are angels, (Which that they may win)
They'll hire the devil to come with false dice in.
O Sirens subtle tunes! yourselves you flatter,
And our weak sex betray, so men love water;
It serves to wash their hands, but (Being once foul)
The water down is poured, cast out of doors,
And even of such base use do men make whores.
A harlot (Like a hen) more sweetness reaps,
To pick men one by one up, then in heaps:
Yet all feeds but confounding. Say you should taste me,
I serve but for the time, and when the day
Of war is done, am cashiered out of pay:
If like lame soldiers I could beg, that's all,
And there's lust's rendezvous, an hospital.
Who then would be a man's slave, a man's woman?
She's half starved the first day that feeds in common.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You should not feed so, but with me alone.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If I drink poison by stealth, is't not all one?
Is't not rank poison still? with you alone!
Nay say you spied a courtesan, whose soft side
To touch, you'd sell your birthright for one kiss,
Be racked, she's won, you're sated: what follows this?
O, than you curse that bawd that towed you in,
(The night) you curse your lust, you loathe the sin,
You loathe her very sight, and ere the day
Arise, you rise glad when you're stolen away.
Even then when you are drunk with all her sweets,
There's no true pleasure in a strumpet's sheets.
Women, whom lust so prostitutes to sale,
Like dancers upon ropes; once seen, are stale.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: If all the threads of harlot's lives are span,
So course as you would make them, tell me why
You so long loved the trade?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If all the threads
Of harlot's lives be fine as you would make them,
Why do not you persuade your wife turn whore,
And all dames else to fall before that sin?
Like an ill husband (Who I knew the same,
To be my undoing) followed I that game.
O when the work of lust had earned my bread,
To taste it, how I trembled, lest each bit,
Ere it went down, should choke me (Chewing it?)
My bed seemed like a cabin hung in hell,
The bawd hell's porter, and the liquorish wine
The pander fetched, was like an easy fine,
For which, methought I leased away my soul,
And oftentimes (Even in my quaffing bowl)
Thus said I to myself, I am a whore,
And have drunk down thus much confusion more.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is a common rule, and 'tis most true,
Two of one trade never love; no more do you.
Why are you sharp 'gainst that you once professed?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why dote you on that, which you did once detest?
I cannot (Seeing she's woven of such bad stuff)
Set colours on a harlot base enough.
Nothing did make me, when I loved them best,
To loathe them more than this: when in the street
A fair young modest damsel I did meet,
She seemed to all a dove (When I passed by)
And I (To all) a raven: every eye
That followed her, wont with a bashful glance
At me, each bold and jeering countenance
Darted forth scorn: to her (As if she had been
Some tower unvanquished) would they veil,
'Gainst me swollen rumor hoist every sail.
She (Crowned with reverend praises) passed by them,
I (Though with face masked) could not scape the hem,
For (As if heaven had set strange marks on whores,
Because they should be pointing stocks to man)
Dressed up in civilest shape a courtesan.
Let her walk saintlike, noteless, and unknown,
Yet she's betrayed by some trick of her own.
Were harlots therefore wise, they'd be sold dear:
For men account them good but for one year:
And then like almanacs (Whose dates are gone)
They are thrown by, and no more looked upon.
Who'll therefore backward fall, who will launch forth
In seas so foul, for ventures no more worth?
Lust's voyage hath (If not this course) this cross,
Buy ne'er so cheap, your ware comes home with loss.
What, shall I sound retreat? the battle's done:
Let the world judge which of us two have won.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You? nay then as cowards do in fight,
What by blows cannot, shall be saved by flight.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fly to earth's fixed centre: to the caves
Of everlasting horror, I'll pursue thee,
(Though loaden with sins) even to hell's brazen doors.
Thus wisest men turn fools, doting on whores.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke, Lodovico, and Orlando: after them Infaelice. Carolo, Astolfo, Beraldo, Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I beseech your grace (Though your eye be so piercing) as under a poor blue coat, to cull out an honest father from an old servingman: yet good my lord discover not the plot to any, but only this gentleman that is now to be an actor in our ensuing comedy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou hast thy wish, Orlando, pass unknown,
Sforza shall only go along with thee,
To see that warrant served upon thy son.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To attach him upon felony, for 2. Pedlars: is't not so?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Right, my noble knight: those pedlars were two knaves of mine; he fleeced the men before, and now he purposes to flay the master. He will rob me, his teeth water to be nibbling at my gold, but this shall hang him by'th gills, till I pull him on shore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away: ply you the business.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Thanks to your grace: but my good lord, for my daughter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You know what I have said.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And remember what I have sworn: she's more honest, on my soul, than one of the Turks wenches, watched by a hundred eunuchs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: So she had need, for the Turks make them whores.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He's a Turk that makes any woman a whore, he's no true christian I'm sure. I commit your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Infaelice.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Signior Friscabaldo.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Frisking again, Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Uds so, Pacheco? we'll have some sport with this warrant: 'tis to apprehend all suspected persons in the house: besides, there's one bots a pander, and one madam horseleech a bawd, that have abused my friend, those two coneys will we ferret into the pursenet.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Let me alone for dabbing them o'th neck: come, come.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do ye hear, gallants? meet me anon at Matheo's.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Th' old fellow sings that note thou didst before,
Only his tunes are, that she is no whore,
But that she sent his letters and his gifts,
Out of a noble triumph o'er his lust,
To show she trampled his assaults in dust.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: 'Tis a good honest servant, that old man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I doubt no less.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: And it may be my husband,
Because when once this woman was unmasked,
he levelled all her thoughts, and made them fit:
Now he'd mar all again, to try his wit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It may be so too, for to turn a harlot
Honest, it must be by strong antidotes,
'Tis rare, as to see panthers change their spots.
And when she's once a star (Fixed) and shines bright,
Though 'twere impiety then to dim her light,
Because we see such tapers seldom burn.
Yet 'tis the pride and glory of some men,
To change her to a blazing star again,
And it may be, Hipollito does no more.
It cannot be, but you're acquainted all
With that same madness of our son-in-law,
That dotes so on a courtesan.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: All the city thinks he's a whoremonger.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Yet I warrant, he'll swear, no man marks him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis like so, for when a man goes a wenching, is as if he had a strong stinking breath, every one smells him out, yet he feels it not, though it be ranker than the sweat of sixteen bearewarders.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I doubt then you have all those stinking breathes,
You might be all smelled out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Troth my lord, I think we are all as you ha' been in your youth when you went a-maying, we all love to hear the cuckoo sing upon other men's trees.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It's well yet you confess: but girl, thy bed
Shall not be parted with a courtesan — 'tis strange,
No frown of mine, no frown of the poor lady,
(My abused child, his wife) no care of fame,
Of honour, heaven or hell, no not that name
Of common strumpet, can affright, or woo
Him to abandon her; the harlot does undo him,
She has bewitched him, robbed him of his shape,
Turned him into a beast, his reason's lost,
You see he looks wild, does he not?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I ha' noted new moons
in's face, my lord, all full of change.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He's no more life unto Hipollito,
Then dead men are to living — never sleeps,
Or if he do, it's dreams; and in those dreams
His arms work, — and then cries — sweet — what's her
Name, what's the drabs name?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: In troth, my lord, I know not,
I know no drabs, not I.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O, Bellafront!
And catching her fast, cries, my Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A drench that's able to kill a horse, cannot kill this disease of smock-smelling, my lord, if it have once eaten deep.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'll try all physic, and this medicine first:
I have directed warrants strong and peremptory
(To purge our city Milan, and to cure the outward
Parts, the suburbs) for the attaching
Of all those women, who (Like gold) want weight,
Cities (Like ships) should have no idle freight.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, my lord, and light wenches are no idle freight,
But what's your grace's reach in this?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This (Carolo.) If she whom my son dotes on,
Be in that master-book enrolled, he'll shame
Ever to approach one of such noted name.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But say she be not?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yet on harlot's heads
New laws shall fall so heavy, and such blows shall
Give to those that haunt them, that Hipollito
(If not for fear of law) for love to her,
If he love truly, shall her bed forbear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Attach all the light heels i'th city, and clap 'em up? why, my lord? you dive into a well unsearchable: all the whores within the walls, and without the walls? I would not be he should meddle with them for ten such dukedoms; the army that you speak on, is able to fill all the prisons within this city, and to leave not a drinking room in any tavern besides.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Those only shall be caught that are of note,
Harlots in each street flow:
The fish being thus i'th net, ourself will sit,
And with eye most severe dispose of it. — come, girl.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Arraign the poor whore.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I'll not miss that sessions.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nor I,
Though I hold up my hand there myself.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Let who will come (My noble chevalier) I can but play the kind host, and bid 'em welcome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: We'll trouble your house (Matheo) but as Dutchmen do in taverns (Drink, be merry, and be gone.)

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Indeed if you be right Dutchmen, if you fall to drinking, you must be gone.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The worst is, my wife is not at home; but we'll fly high (My generous knight) for all that: there's no music when a woman is in the consort.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: No, for she's like a pair of virginals,
Always with jacks at her tail.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: See, the covey is sprung.

sp.speaker: O .
sp.l: Save you gallants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Happily encountered, sweet bloods.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you all know signior Candido, the linen draper, he that's more patient than a brown baker, upon the day when he heats his oven, and has forty scolds about him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Yes, we know him all, what of him?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Would it not be a good fit of mirth, to make a piece of English cloth of him, and to stretch him on the tainters, till the threads of his own natural humour crack, by making him drink healths, tobacco, dance, sing bawdy songs, or to run any bias according as we think good to cast him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: 'Twere a morris dance worth the seeing.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: But the old fox is so crafty, we shall hardly hunt out of his den.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: To that train I ha' given fire already; and the hook to draw him hither, is to see certain pieces of lawn, which I told him I have to sell, and indeed have such: fetch them down, Pacheco.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I'm your water-spaniel, and will fetch any thing: but I'll fetch one dish of meat anon, shall turn your stomach, and that's a constable.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What galley-foist is this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Peace, two dishes of stewed prunes, a bawd and a pander. My worthy lieutenant bots; why, now I see thou'rt a-man of thy word, welcome; welcome mistress horseleech: pray gentlemen, salute this reverend matron.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.l: Thanks to all your worships.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I bade a drawer send in wine too: did none come along with thee (Grannam) but the lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: None came along with me but bots, if it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Who the pox should come along with you but bots?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: O brave! march fair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are you come? that's well.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Here's ordnance able to sack a city.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come, repeat, read this inventory.

sp.speaker: 1. Uint.
sp.p: Imprimis, a pottle of Greek wine, a pottle of Peter sa meene, a pottle of Charnico, and a pottle of ziattica.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You're paid?

sp.speaker: 2. Uint.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So shall some of us be anon, I fear.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Here's a hot day towards: but zounds, this is the
life out of which a soldier sucks sweetness, when this artillery goes off roundly, some must drop to the ground: cannon, demi-canon, saker, and basalisk.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Give fire, lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: So, so: must I venture first upon the breach? to you all, gallants: bots sets upon you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Its hard (Bots) if we pepper not you, as well as you pepper us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My noble linen Draper! Some wine: welcome old lad.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You're welcome, signior.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: These lawns, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Presently, my man is gone for them: we ha' rigged a fleet, you see here, to sail about the world.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: A dangerous voyage, sailing in such ships.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: There's no casting over board yet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Because you are an old lady, I will have you be acquainted with this grave citizen, pray bestow your lips upon him, and bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Any citizen shall be most welcome to me: — I have used to buy ware at your shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It may be so, good madam.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Your prentices know my dealings well; I trust your good wife be in good case: if it please you, bear her a token from my lips, by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I pray no more forsooth, 'tis very well, indeed I love no sweet meats: — sh'as a breath stinks worse than fifty polecats. Sir, a word, is she a lady?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A woman of a good house, and an ancient, she's a bawd.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: A bawd? Sir, I'll steal hence, and see your lawns some other time.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Steal out of such company? Pacheco? my man is but gone for 'em: lieutenant bots, drink to this worthy old fellow, and teach him to fly high.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Swagger: and make him do't on his knees.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How, bots? now bless me, what do I with bots? no wine in sooth, no wine, good master bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Graybeard, goat's pizzle: 'tis a health, have this in your guts, or this, there: I will sing a bawdy song, sir, because your verge's face is melancholy, to make liquor go down glib: will you fall on your maribones, and pledge this health, 'tis to my mistress, a whore?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Here's ratsbane upon ratsbane: master bots, I pray, sir, pardon me: you are a soldier, press me not to this service, I am old, and shoot not in such potguns.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Cap, I'll teach you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: To drink healths, is to drink sickness: gentlemen, pray rescue me.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Zounds, who dare?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We shall ha' stabbing then?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I ha' reckonings to cast up, good master bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: This will make you cast 'em up better.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why does your hand shake so?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The palsy, signiors, danceth in my blood.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Pipe with a pox, sir, then, or I'll make your blood dance —

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Hold, hold, good master bots, I drink.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: To the old countess there.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: To me, old boy? this is he that never drunk wine: once again to't.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: With much ado the poison is got down,
Though I can scarce get up; never before
Drank I a whore's health, nor will never more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hast been at gallows?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes, sir, for I make account to suffer today.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Look, signior: here's the commodity.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Your price?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thus.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: No: too dear: thus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No: oh fie, you must sly higher: yet take 'em home, trifles shall not make us quarrel, we'll agree, you shall have them, and a pennyworth, I'll fetch money at your shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Be it so, good signior, send me going.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Going? A deep bowl of wine for signior Candido.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: He would be going.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I'll rather stay, then go so: stop your bowl.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Is't Shrove-tuesday, that these ghosts walk.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What's your business, sir?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: From the Duke: you are the man we look for, signior, I have warrant here from the Duke, to apprehend you upon felony for robbing two pedlars: I charge you i'th Duke's name go quickly.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is the wind turned? well: this is that old wolf, my father-in-law: seek out your mistress, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes, sir: as shafts by piecing are made strong,
So shall thy life be straightened by this wrong.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: In troth we are sorry.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Brave men must be crossed, pish, it's but fortune's dice roving against me: come, sir, pray use me like a gentleman, let me not be carried through the streets like a pageant.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: If these gentlemen please, you shall go along with them.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Be't so: come.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Ay, sir? sometimes a figure, sometimes a cipher, as the state has occasion to cast up her accounts: I'm a soldier.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Your name is bots, is't not?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Bots is my name, bots is known to this company.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: I know you are, sir: what's she?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: A gentlewoman, my mother.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Take 'em both along.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Me? Sir.

sp.speaker: Billmen.
sp.l: And sir.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: If he swagger, raise the street.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Gentlemen, gentlemen, whither will you drag us?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To the garden house. Bots, are we even with you?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: To Bridewell with 'em.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: You will answer this.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Better then a challenge, I have warrant for my work, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We'll go before.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Pray do.
sp.p: Who, signior Candido? A citizen of your degree consorted thus, and revelling in such a house?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Why, sir? what house I pray?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Lewd, and defamed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Is't so? thanks, sir: I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: What have you there?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Lawns which I bought, sir, of the gentleman that keeps the house.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: And I have warrant here, to search for such stolen ware: these lawns are stolen.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: So he's the thief, you the receiver: I'm sorry for this chance, I must commit you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Me, sir, for what?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: These goods are found upon you, and you must answer't.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Must I so?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Most certain.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I'll send for bail.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I dare not: yet because you are a citizen of worth, you shall not be made a pointing stock, but without guard pass only with myself.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: To Bridewell too?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: No remedy.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Yes, patience: being not mad, they had me once to bedlam,
sp.l: Now I'm drawn to Bridewell, loving no whores.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: You will buy lawn? —
sp.stage: Enter at one door Hipollito; at another, Lodovico, Astolfo, Carolo, Beraldo, Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yonder's the lord Hipollito, by any means leave him and me together: now will I turn him to a madman.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Save you, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I ha strange news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your mare's i'th pound.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your nightingale is in a limebush.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your puritanical honest whore sits in a blue gown.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Blue gown!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She'll chalk out your way to her now: she beats chalk.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Where, who dares?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Do you know the brick-house of castigation, by the riverside that runs by Milan: the school where they pronounce no letter well but o?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I know it not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Any man that has born office of constable, or any woman that has fallen from a horseload to a cartload, or like an old hen that has had none but rotten eggs in her nest, can direct you to her: there you shall see your punk amongst her back-friends, there you may have her at your will, for there she beats chalk, or grinds in the mill, with a whip deedle, deedle, deedle, deedle; ah little monkey.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What rogue durst serve that warrant, knowing I loved her?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Some worshipful rascal, I lay my life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll beat the lodgings down about their ears
That are her keepers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: So you may bring an old house over her head.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll to her —
I'll to her, stood armed fiends to guard the doors.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O me! what monsters are men made by whores?
If this false fire do kindle him, there's one faggot
More to the bonfire, now to my Bridewell birds,
What song will they sing?
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Carolo, Astolfo, Beraldo, Fontinell, three or four masters of Bridewell: Infaelice.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your Bridewell? that the name? for beauty, strength,
Capacity and form of ancient building,
(Besides the river's neighbourhood) few houses
Wherein we keep our court can better it.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Hither from foreign courts have princes come,
And with our Duke did acts of state commence,
Here that great Cardinal had first audience,
(The grave campaign,) that Duke dead, his son
(That famous prince) gave free possession
Of this his palace, to the citizens,
To be the poor man's warehouse: and endowed it
With lands to'th value of seven hundred mark,
With all the bedding and the furniture, once proper
(As the lands then were) to an hospital
Belonging to a Duke of Savoy. Thus
Fortune can toss the world, a prince's court
Is thus a prison now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis fortune's sport:
These changes common are: the wheel of fate
Turns kingdoms up, till they fall desolate.
But how are these seven hundred marks by'th year
Employed in this your workhouse?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: War and peace
Feed both upon those lands: when the iron doors
Of wars burst open, from this house are sent
Men furnished in all martial compliment.
The moon hath thorough her bow scarce drawn to'th head,
(Like to twelve silver arrows) all the months,
since 1600. Soldiers went aboard:
Here providence and charity play such parts,
The house is like a very school of arts,
For when our soldiers (Like ships driven from sea,
With ribs all broken, and with tattered sides,)
Cast anchor here again, their ragged backs
How often do we cover? that (Like men)
They may be sent to their own homes again.
All here are but one swarm of bees, and strive
To bring with wearied thighs honey to the hive.
The sturdy beggar, and the lazy loon,
Gets here hard hands, or laced correction.
The vagabond grows stayed, and learns to 'Obey,
The drone is beaten well, and sent away
As other prisons are, (Some for the thief,
Some, by which undone credit gets relief
From bridled debtors; others for the poor)
So this is for the bawd, the rogue, and whore.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: An excellent teem of horse.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Nor is it seen,
That the whip draws blood here, to cool the spleen
Of any rugged bencher: nor does offence
Feel smart, or spiteful, or rash evidence:
But pregnant testimony forth must stand,
Ere justice leave them in the beadle's hand,
As iron, on the anvil are they laid,
Not to take blows alone, but to be made
And fashioned to some charitable use.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thus wholsom'st laws spring from the worst abuse.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let mercy touch your heartstrings (Gracious lord)
That it may sound like music in the ear
Of a man desperate, (Being i'th hands of law.)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Matheo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: For a robbery? where is she?
sp.stage: Exit Bel. and one of the masters of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: In this house.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Fetch you him hither —
Is this the party?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: This is the hen, my lord, that the cock (With the lordly comb) your son-in-law would crow over, and tread.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are your two servants ready?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: My two pedlars are packed together, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis well: this day in judgement shall be spent,
Vice (Like a wound lanced) mends by punishment.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Let me be gone, my lord, or stand unseen;
'Tis rare when a judge strikes, and that none die,
And 'tis unfit then, women should be by.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: We'll place you, lady, in some private room.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Pray do so.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thus nice dames swear, it is unfit their eyes
Should view men carved up for anatomies,
Yet they'll see all, so they may stand unseen,
Many women sure will sin behind a screen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your son (The lord Hipollito) is entered.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Tell him we wish his presence. A word Storsa:
On what wings flew he hither?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: These, I told him — his lark whom he loved, was a Bridewell bird, he's mad that this cage should hold her, and is come to let her out.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent: away, go call him hither.
sp.stage: Enter one of the governors of the house, Bellafront after him with Matheo, after him the constable. Enter at another door, Lodovico and Hipollito: Orlando steps forth and brings in two pedlars.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are to us a stranger (Worthy lord)
'Tis strange to see you here.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is most fit,
That where the sun goes, attorneys follow it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Attorneys neither shape, nor honour bear:
Be you yourself, a sunbeam to shine clear.
Is this the gentleman? Stand forth and hear your accusation.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll hear none: I fly high in that: rather than kites shall seize upon me, and pick out mine eyes to my face, I'll strike my talons thorough mine own heart first, and spit my blood in theirs: I am here for shriving those two fools of their sinful pack: when those jackdaws have cawed over me, then must I cry guilty, or not guilty; the law has work enough already, and therefore I'll put no work of mine into his hands, the hangman shall have't first, I did pluck those ganders, did rob them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis well done to confess.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Confess and be hanged, and then I fly high, is't not so? that for that a gallows is the worst rub that a good bowler can meet with: I stumbled against such a post, else this night I had played the part of a true son in these days, undone my father-in-law, with him would I ha' run at leapfrog, and come over his gold, though I had broke his neck for't: but the poor salmon trout is now in the net.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And now the law must teach you to fly high.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Right, my lord, and then may you fly low; no more words, a mouse, mum, you are stopped.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be good to my poor husband, dear my lords.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ass, why shouldst thou pray them to be good to me, when no man here is good to one another?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Did any hand work in this theft but yours?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, yes, my lord, yes: — the hangman has never one son at a birth, his children always come by couples: though I cannot give the old dog, my father, a bone to gnaw, the daughter shall be sure of a choke-pear. — yes, my lord, there was one more that fiddled my fine pedlars, and that was my wife.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Alas, I?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O everlasting, supernatural superlative villain!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Your wife, Matheo?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sure it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, sir, you love no quarters of mutton that hang up, you love none but whole mutton; she set the robbery, I performed it; she spurred me on, I galloped away.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: My lords.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My lords, (Fellow give me speech) if my poor life
May ransom thine, I yield it to the law,
Thou hurtest thy soul (Yet wipest off no offence)
By casting blots upon my innocence:
Let not these spare me, but tell truth: no, see
Who slips his neck out of the misery,
Though not out of the mischief: let thy servant
That shared in this base act, accuse me here,
Why should my husband perish, he go clear?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: A god child, hang thine own father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Old fellow, was thy hand in too?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: My hand was in the pie, my lord, I confess it: my mistress I see, will bring me to the gallows, and so leave me; but I'll not leave her so: I had rather hang in a woman's company, then in a man's; because if we should go to hell together, I should scarce be letten in, for all the devils are afraid to have any women come amongst them, as I am true thief, she neither consented to this felony, nor knew of it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What fury prompts thee on to kill thy wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: It's my humour, sir, 'tis a foolish bagpipe that I make myself merry with: why should I eat hempseed at the hangman's thirteen-pence halfpenny ordinary, and have this whore laugh at me as I swing, as I totter?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is she a whore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A sixpenny mutton pastry, for any to cut up.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Ah, toad, toad, toad.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A barber's cittern for every servingman to play upon, that lord, your son, knows it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ay, sir, am I her bawd then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, sir, but she's your whore then,

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yea spider, dost catch at great flies?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My whore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I cannot talk, sir, and tell of your reins, and your fees, and your whirligigs, and devices: but, my lord, I found 'em like sparrows in one nest, billing together, and bulling of me, I took 'em in bed, was ready to kill him was up to stab her —

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Close thy rank jaws: pardon me, I am vexed,
Thou art a villain, a malicious devil,
Deep as the place where thou art lost, thou liest,
Since I am thus far got into this storm,
I'll thorough, and thou shalt see I'll thorough untouched.
When thou shalt perish in it.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: 'Tis my cue
To enter now: room, let my prize be played,
I ha' lurked in clouds, yet heard what all have said,
What jury more can prove, she has wronged my bed,
Than her own husband, she must be punished;
I challenge law, my lord, letters, and gold, and jewels
From my lord that woman took.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Against that black-mouthed devil, against letters, and gold,
And against a jealous wife I do uphold,
Thus far her reputation, I could sooner
Shake the Apennine, and crumble rocks to dust,
Then (Though Jove's shower rained down) tempt her to lust.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Say thou art not a whore, and that's more than fifteen women (Amongst five hundred) dare swear without lying: this shalt thou say, no let me say't for thee; thy husband's a knave, this lord's an honest man; thou art no punk, this lady's a right lady. Pacheco is a thief as his master is, but old Orlando is as true a man as thy father is: I ha' seen you fly high, sir, and I ha' seen you fly low, sir, and to keep you from the gallows, sir, a blue coat have I worn, and a thief did I turn, mine own men are the pedlars, my
twenty pound did fly high, sir, your wife's gown did fly low, sir: whither fly you now, sir? you ha' scaped the gallows, to the devil you fly next, sir. Am I right, my liege?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your father has the true physician played.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And I am now his patient.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And be so still, 'tis a good sign when our cheeks blush at ill.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: The linen Draper (Signior Candido)
He whom the city terms the patient man,
Is likewise here for buying of those lawns
The pedlars lost.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Alas good Candido.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Fetch him: and when these payments up are cast,
Weigh out your light gold, but let's have them last.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In Bridewell, Candido?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Yes, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What make you here?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My lord, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'm here to save right, and to drive wrong hence.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: And I to bear wrong here with patience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You ha' bought stolen goods.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: So they do say, my lord,
Yet bought I them upon a gentleman's word,
And imagine now, as I thought then,
That there be thieves, but no thieves gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your credit's cracked being here.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: No more than gold
Being cracked which does his estimation hold.
I was in bedlam once, but was I mad?
They made me pledge whores healths, but am I bad,
Because I'm with bad people?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, stand by,
If you take wrong, we'll cure the injury.
sp.stage: Enter constable, after them bots, after him two beadles, one with hemp, the other with a beetle.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stay, stay, what's he? A prisoner?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He seems a soldier?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: I am what I seem, sir, one of fortune's bastards, a soldier, and a gentleman, and am brought in here with master constable's band of billmen, because they face me down that I live (Like those that keep bowling-alleys) by the sins of the people, in being a squire of the body.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O, an apple-squire.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Yes, sir, that degree of scurvy squires, and that I am maintained by the best part that is commonly in a woman, by the worst players of those parts, but I am known to all this company.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My lord, 'tis true, we all know him, 'tis lieutenant bots.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bots, and where ha' you served, bots?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: In most of your hottest services in the Low-countries: at the groin I was wounded in this thigh, and halted upon't, but 'tis now sound. In Cleveland I missed but little, having the bridge of my nose broken down with two great stones, as I was scaling a fort: I ha' been tried, sir, too, in Gelderland, and scaped hardly there from being blown up at a breach: I was fired, and lay i'th surgeons hands for't, till the fall of the leaf following.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: All this may be, and yet you no soldier.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: No soldier, sir? I hope these are services that your proudest commanders do venture upon, and never come off sometimes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, sir, because you say you are a soldier,
I'll use you like a gentleman: make room there,
Plant him amongst you, we shall have anon
Strange hawks fly here before us: if none light on you,
You shall with freedom take your flight:
but if you prove a bird of baser wing,
We'll use you like such birds, here you shall sing.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: I wish to be tried at no other weapon.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, is he furnished with those in payments?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: The pander is more dangerous to a state,
Then is the common thief, and though our laws
Lie heavier on the thief, yet that the pander
May know the hangman's ruff should fit him too,
Therefore he's set to beat hemp.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This does savour
Of justice, basest slaves to basest labour.
Now pray, set open hell, and let us see
The shee-deuils that are here.

sp.speaker: Infa.
sp.l: Methinks this place
Should make even Lais honest.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Some it turns good,
But (As some men whose hands are once in blood,
Do in a pride spill more) so, some going hence,
Are (By being here) lost in more impudence:
Let it not to them (When they come) appear,
That any one does as their judge sit here:
But that as gentlemen you come to see,
And then perhaps their tongues will walk more free.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let them be marshaled in: be covered all,
Fellows, now to make the scene more comical.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Will not you be smelled out, bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: No, your bravest whores have the worst noses.
sp.stage: Enter two of the masters: a constable after them, then Dorathes target, brave, after her two beadles, th'one with a wheel, the other with a blue gown.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are not you a bride, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Say ye?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He would know if these be not your bridemen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Vuh, yes, sir: and look ye, do you see the bride-laces that I give at my wedding, will serve to tie rosemary
to both your coffins when you come from hanging-scab ▪

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Fie, punk, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Out you stale stinking head of garlic, foh, at my heels.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: My head's cloven.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O, let the gentlewoman alone, she's going to shrift.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Nay to do penance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ay, ay, go punk, go to the cross and be whipped.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Marry mew, marry muff, marry hang you goodman dog: whipped? do ye take me for a base spittle whore? in troth gentlemen, you wear the clothes of gentlemen, but you carry not the minds of gentlemen, to abuse a gentlewoman of my fashion.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Fashion? pox a your fashions, art not a whore?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Goodman slave.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O fie, abuse her not, let us two talk,
What might I call your name, pray?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'm not ashamed of my name, sir, my name is mistress Doll target, a western gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Her target against any pike in Milan.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why is this wheel born after her?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: She must spin.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A course thread it shall be, as all threads are.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: If you spin, than you'll earn money here too?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I had rather get half a crown abroad, than ten crowns here.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Abroad? I think so.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Dost thou not weep now thou art here?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Say ye? weep? yes forsooth, as you did when you lost your maidenhead: do you not hear how I weep?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Farewell Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Farewell dog.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Past shame: past penitence, why is that blue gown?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Being stripped out of her wanton loose attire,
That garment she puts on, base to the eye,
Only to clothe her in humility.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are all the rest like this?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: No, my good lord.
You see, this drab swells with a wanton rein,
The next that enters has a different strain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Variety is good, let's see the rest.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Your grace sees I'm sound yet, and no bullets hit me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come off so, and 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Here's the second mess.
sp.stage: Enter the two masters, after them the constable, after him Penelope Whorehound, like a citizen's wife, after her two beadles, one with a blue gown, another with chalk and a mallet.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I ha' worn many a costly gown, but I was never thus guarded with blue coats, and beadles, and constables, and —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alas fair mistress, spoil not thus your eyes.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: O sweet sir, I fear the spoiling of other places about me that are dearer than my eyes; if you be gentlemen, if you be men, or ever came of a woman, pity my case, stand to me, stick to me, good sir, you are an old man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Hang not on me, I prithee, old trees bear no such fruit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Will you bail me, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Bail thee, art in for debt?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: No — is my judge, sir, I am in for no debts, I paid my tailor for this gown, the last five shillings a week that was behind, yesterday.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What is your name, I pray?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Penelope Whorehound, I come of the Whorehounds. How does lieutenant bots.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A ha bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: A very honest woman, as I'm a soldier, a pox bots ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
I was never in this pickle before, and yet if I go amongst citizens' wives, they jeer at me: if I go among the loose-bodied gowns, they cry a pox on me, because I go civilly attired, and swear their trade was a good
trade, till such as I am taken it out of their hands: good lieutenant bots, speak to these captains to bail me.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p: Begging for bail still? you are a trim gossip, go give her the blue gown, set her to her chare, work housewife, for your bread, away.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Out you dog, a pox on you all, women are born to curse thee, but I shall live to see twenty such flatcaps shaking dice for a pennyworth of pippins: out, you blue-eyed rogue.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Even now she wept, and prayed, now does she curse?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p: Seeing me: if still she had stayed, this had been worse.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Was she ever here before?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Five times at least,
And thus if men come to her, have her eyes wrung, and
Wept out her bail.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Bots, you know her?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Is there any gentleman here, that knows not a
Whore, and is he a hair the worse for that?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is she a city-dame, she's so attired?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: No, my good lord, that's only but the veil
To her loose body, I have seen her here
In gayer masking suits, as several sauces
Give one dish several tastes, so change of habits
In whores is a bewitching art: today she's all in
Colours to besot gallants, then in modest black,
To catch the citizen, and this from their examinations
Drawn, now shall you see a monster both in shape
And nature quite from these, that sheds no tear,
Nor yet is nice, 'tis a plain ramping bear,
Many such whales are cast upon this shore.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Let's see her.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Then behold a swaggering whore.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Keep your ground, bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: I do but traverse to spy advantage how to arm myself.
sp.stage: Enter the two masters first, after them the constable, after them a beadle beating a basin, then Catyryna bountinall, with mistress horseleech, after them another beadle with a blue head guarded with yellow.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Sirrah, when I cry hold your hands, hold, you rogue-catcher, hold: bawd, are the French chilblains in your heels, that you can come no faster? are not you (Bawd) a whore's ancient, and must not I follow my colours?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: O mistress Katherine, you do me wrong to accuse me here as you do, before the right worshipful: I am known for a motherly honest woman, and no bawd.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Marry foh, honest? burned at fourteen, seven times whipped, six times carted, nine times ducked, searched by some hundred and fifty constables, and yet you are honest? Honest mistress horseleech, is this world, a world to keep bawds and whores honest? How many times hast thou given gentlemen a quart of wine in a gallon pot? how many twelvepenny fees, nay two shillings fees, nay, when any ambassadors ha' been here, how many half crown fees hast thou taken? how many carriers hast thou bribed for country wenches? how often have I rinsed your lungs in aquavitae, and yet you are honest?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And what were you the whilst?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Marry hang you, master slave, who made you an examiner?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well said, belike this devil spares no man.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: What art thou prithee?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Nay what art thou prithee?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: A whore, art thou a thief?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: A thief, no, I defy the calling, I am a soldier, have born arms in the field, been in many a hot skirmish, yet come off sound.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Sound with a pox to ye, ye abominable rogue! you a soldier? you in skirmishes? where? amongst pottle pots in a bawdy-house? Look, look here, you madam
Wormeaten, do not you know him?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Lieutenant bots, where have ye been this many a day?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Old bawd, do not discredit me, seem not to know me.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Not to know ye, master bots? as long as I have breath, I cannot forget thy sweet face.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why, do you know him? he says he is a soldier.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: He a soldier? A pander, a dog that will lick up six pence: do ye hear, you master swine's snout, how long is't since you held the door for me, and cried to't again, nobody comes, ye rogue you?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, you're smelled out again, bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Pox ruin her nose for't, and I be not revenged for this — 'em ye bitch.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: D'ye ye hear ye madam? why does your ladyship swagger thus? you're very brave, methinks .

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Not at your cost, master codshead,
Is any man here blear-eyed to see me brave?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Yes, I am,
Because good clothes upon a whore's back
Is like fair painting upon a rotten wall.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Marry muff master whoremaster, you come upon me with sentences.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By this light has small sense for't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O fie, fie, do not vex her.
And yet methinks a creature of more scurvy conditions
Should not know what a good petticoat were.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Marry come out,
sp.p: You're so busy about my petticoat, you'll creep up to my placket, and ye could but attain the honour, but and the outsides offend your rogueships, look o'the lining, 'tis silk.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is't silk 'tis lined with then?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Silk? I silk, master slave, you would be glad to wipe your nose with the skirt on't: this 'tis to come among
a company of codsheads that know not how to use a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Tell her the Duke is here.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Be modest, Kata, the Duke is here.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: If the devil were here, I care not: set forward, ye rogues, and give attendance according to your places, let bawds and whores be sad, for I'll sing and the devil were a dying.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why before her does the basin ring?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: It is an emblem of their revelling,
The whips we use let's forth their wanton blood,
Making them calm, and more to calm their pride,
In stead of coaches they in carts do ride.
Will your grace see more of this bad ware?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, shut up shop, we'll now break up the fair,
Yet ere we part — you, sir, that take upon ye
The name of soldier, that true name of worth,
Which, action not vain boasting best sets forth,
To let you know how far a soldier's name
Stands from your title, and to let you see,
Soldiers must not be wronged where princes be:
This be your sentence.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Defend yourself, bots.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: First, all the private sufferance that the house
Inflicts upon offenders, you (As the basest)
Shall undergo it double, after which
You shall be whipped, sir, round about the city,
Then banished from the land.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away with him, see it done, panders and whores
Are city-plagues, which being kept alive,
Nothing that looks like goodness ere can thrive.
Now good Orlando, what say you to your bad son-in-law ▪

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Marry this, my lord, he is my son-in-law, and in law will I be his father: for if law can pepper him, he shall be so parboiled, that he shall stink no more i'th nose of the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be yet more kind and merciful, good father.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Dost thou beg for him, thou precious man's meat, thou? has he not beaten thee, kicked thee, trod on thee, and dost thou fawn on him like his spaniel? has he not pawned thee to thy petticoat, sold thee to thy smock, made ye leap at a crust, yet wouldst have me save him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O yes, good sir, women shall learn of me,
To love their husbands in greatest misery,
Then show him pity, or you wrack myself.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Have ye eaten pigeons that you're so kindhearted to your mate? Nay, you're a couple of wild bears, I'll have ye both baited at one stake: but as for this knave, the gallows is thy due, and the gallows thou shalt have, I'll have justice of the Duke, the law shall have thy life, what, dost thou hold him? let go his hand: if thou dost not forsake him, a father's everlasting blessing fall upon both your heads: away, go, kiss out of my sight, play thou the whore no more, nor thou the thief again, my house shall be thine, my meat shall be thine, and so shall my wine, but my money shall be mine, and yet when I die, (So thou dost not fly high) take all, yet good Matheo, mend.
sp.l: Thus for joy weeps Orlando, and doth end.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then hear, Matheo: all your woes are stayed
By your good father-in-law: all your ills
Are clear purged from you by his working pills.
Come signior Candido, these green young wits
(We see by circumstance) this plot hath laid,
Still to provoke thy patience, which they find
A wall of brass, no armour's like the mind;
Thou hast taught the city patience, now our court
Shall be thy sphere, where from thy good report,
Rumours this truth unto the world shall sing,
A patient man's a pattern for a King.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
